posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>>9559780
Not all though. Really old ones? Mostly yes. Blackbox era ones? Wouldn't say so. Post Blackbox era ones? Not really.
Driving most of RWD cars with automatic tranny is absolute pain in Blackbox era games. You end up doing burnouts because revs are jumping like crazy and launch control is not existing thing for most RWD cars. That's why you have to shift gears early and don't go below 3rd gear and below 4-5K RPM, otherwise you'll potentially spin out and end up doing burnouts. In Carbon despite launch control being better, you'd end up losing at least 10% of cars' real performance if you don't play with manual because automatic would cut off too early. In ProStreet manual + clutch is must have, otherwise you won't see true cars' potential. In Undercover it's same as Carbon.

posts.com:
>>9555378
That's entirely on Nintendo of America.

By the time Super Bomberman 3 released in Japan, Hudson Soft USA was closed and had to cancel localizations for Super Bonk 2 and Elfaria (possibly in collaboration with Working Designs, but Hudson would still publish)

Nintendo chose to pick up Super Bomberman 3 and Nintendo of America staff worked on the localization and game testing (there's even footage in a Japanese documentary) much like with Terranigma, they just chose to release it only in Europe.

It's not too weird, because NoE was still a subsidary of NoA and translators were really discouraged from learning Japanese directly (not that it kept them from doing it anyways, and the Japanese staff from appreciating it, and for them to eventually get their autonomy to reduce the +1 year release schedule gaps), but Nintendo of America's weird insistence on killing the SNES as soon as 1995 was something. Metal Warriors by LucasArts was supposed to be a Nintendo-published game too, and they planned an English localization of DBZ Super Butoden 2 (simply called Dragon Ball) in 1996 meant for Mexican audiences.

>>9555689
Scandinavia has its own Nintendo distribution. When Nintendo was busy getting fucked over by Atari (failed 1983 American Famicom launch as rebranded Atari, Atari intended to bury Nintendo alive by sitting on the rights all along, Nintendo headhunted some of those Atari marketing teams and tried to slowly piece together its own distribution) and Mattel/Bandai (European distribution until 1993), the Scandinavian branch was the only one actually doing its job, and even getting titles sooner than other regions.

>>9555732
Sony SCEA rejects 2D game > publisher tries to release it in Europe, if the licensing deal doesn't make it impossible to release altogether (like Capcom's Dungeons & Dragons PS1, which culminated in a standoff over Mega Man 8 and Resident Evil on the Saturn and not just a different region)
Happened a lot on the PS1.

I live in Japan and I go to thrift stores occasionally to pick up games to play. Over the past few years I've watched the prices steadily climb and it's really sad to see. But it's not all games. Mostly it's the stuff that importers want, like Pokemon and Chrono Trigger.

A few years ago you could get all of the old Pokemon games CIB for under $10, but now they sell for much more and they get locked in a case with the rare games now. The other day I saw a CIB copy of Pokemon Blue for over $100, that was insane. A lot of old RPGs that used to be like $3 CIB have also climbed in price for CIB versions (but loose versions are pretty cheap still).

I'm not really affected by it since I already have a lot of the games that I care about, but I have this attitude that games are for playing so I'm bothered by this the same way I'm bothered by graded games. Ok let this isn't Mario or whatever, you can't play an RPG if you don't know Japanese and the majority of import fags don't. These guys are buying these just to put on a shelf and collect dust as a display piece because they can't afford a copy in their own language and they need it as an excuse to justify emulation. Meanwhile Japanese gamers who largely rely on buying/reselling to thrift shops (a lot of people don't have space for large collections) are stuck with the higher prices.

You ruined your own game market already. Don't ruin other game markets.

>>9563632
Amagami sure did deserve far more respect than the fan """"translation"""" gave it. I usually don't feel sorry for EOPs but Amagami is a pretty legendary game that represents the peak of dating simulation VNs, and honestly, even those damn EOPs deserved better too.
It's a game that, to this very day, still gets hundreds if not thousands of social media posts daily, fan art, and even official stuff like the ASMR series with the same CVs from the game. There's no clear answer besides 塚原先輩 as to who the best girl is, because they're all excellent in their own way. And it's perhaps one of the easiest of its genre to get into, since you don't need to consult a guide at any point to confirm which obscure thing you have to do next, or which combination of stats you have to raise in x or y order to unlock event z at points a, b, and c of the timeline (where all 3 are easily missable).
So, how did such a respected title get such a disrespectful translation effort that spanned over a decade, only to be released in a buggy, unfinished, inaccurate state? It's a mystery. But moreover, it was so bad that it singlehandedly killed any interest in it, when it SHOULD have been opening a door for people to enjoy it instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562387
>What makes this game so great?
No quest markers or fast travel (outside of catching rides between trade posts).
Not ruined by difficulty scaling like the rest of the series.
Actual good lore (and even better secret lore (and even better secret secret lore)).
Unique world building and aesthetics.
Wacky and exploitable gamesystems like spellcrafting that rewards creativity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562387
I guess I'll try and explain the appeal of the game for me:
>true adventure, you are left to your own devices, no hand holding
>custom magic spells are really fun to experiment with
>its a rags to riches type of game, you start as a noob and gradually become more powerful
>you grow an intimate understanding of the land throughout the game as you are forced to learn landmarks, factions, travel methods, backstory, etc.
>the fast travel systems are all in universe, use silt striders, boats, mages guilds to travel between cities, use your own spells to create a custom waypoint
>there is actual unique loot to find in the world, its not level scaled random loot like the other elder scrolls
>main story is VERY interesting and compelling
>just the feel of completing even a simple quest is adventurous because you are navigating based on the journals directions and your knowledge of the land

It's true that you don't get much influence in how quests play out, since most of them are task oriented.
However, variance in your playthrough will depend on WHICH factions and characters you decide to do quests for.
Factions have base stat requirements and some are mutually exclusive with others (not all though).
On top of that the music, aesthetic, and worldbuilding are all A+ so it's just enjoyable to be in Vvardenfell.

My advice is to take it super slow, don't expect it to be a masterpiece in the first hour. Your character will be a low level piece of shit that can barely hit a target or run faster than a slug.
Remember you can hold attack to charge hits and don't fight with low stamina because it affects your hit chance.
If you give the game a chance you will fall in love with the world because of how intimately you are made to learn and interact with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Neat world with lots of places to find, lots to see and dig around in. Horrible combat and a plotline you need to put effort into giving a shit about. There's a billion items to find, but most of them don't really matter. You are given pretty much complete freedom to do whatever you want. Balance is kinda fucked, spells and skills range from worthless to entirely broken. Still pretty cool being able to fly around the world or run at Sanic speeds. Even at it's most patched and fixed, it's still buggy, glitchy, and very unstable. OpenMW doesn't exist because it's hard to run on modern OS'es, it exists to try and create a version of Morrowind that's actually stable and bug-free without trying to reverse engineer and fix every problem. The game came with the tool the devs themselves used to setup the game world and many features, allowing you to mod the game extensively. The game also supports these modifications natively as plug-ins, allowing you to turn them on and off from the main menu.
It's a mixed bag as a whole, but it has a lot going for it. It was also the first open-world fully-3D RPG on a console that I can think of. Computers had that years before Morrowind was released, but I can't think of any console RPGs that were fully-3D prior to the 6th generation, and open-world as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9554771
There's been a few.
>owner of Color Dreams sees Hellraiser in theaters
>blown the fuck away
>decides that he HAS to make a game out of this somehow
>actually manages to wrangle a license for the Hellraiser IP
>it's gonna be on the NES
>also it's gonna use a special cartridge with an extra processor to make an even more advanced game
>planned sfuff like procedurally generated levels (and maybe demons?)
>some experimenting is done with the prototype cartridge they built, but the realization sets in pretty quickly that this game is going to be quite expensive to produce, meaning it's going to be quite expensive to buy
>also Color Dreams is not licensed by Nintendo so distribution and sales are never easy for them to begin with
>game gets shelved
>some years later (probably 1992 or 1993), they get the itch to try again, and they still have the license
>get the idea to license the Wolfenstein 3D engine from iD Software
>do a bit of work on this as a PC game, but then iD Software starts showing, and eventually releasing, Doom
>a game about demons and hell which would make their effort look incredibly dated and primitive in comparison
>the time for their licensing deal expires soon as well, so they decide "Fuck it." and scrap the game
>famously, Color Dreams rebrands to Wisdom Tree and focus on making Christianity themed games to sell via religious channels (where Nintendo couldn't throw any of their weight around, because they weren't distributing anything themselves around those parts)
>as Wisdom Tree, they make an unlicenses SNES game about Noah's Ark, using the Wolfenstein 3D engine they licensed
>no idea if they got any further technical assistance from iD, but supposedly the guys all thought it was incredibly funny
I don't think any pictures of gameplay or anything ever surfaced of the planned NES game, just a couple of (probably mockup) title screens. Some assets from the PC game were actually released much later on, it looks pretty preliminary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There was another game started by another company (Magnetic Interactive or something like that) in 1995, Hellraiser : Virtual Hell. This used the Build Engine, and was supposed to be about advanced virtual reality research accidentally "reaching hell", supposedly it was meant to feature a mix of different kinds of gameplay, as well as going from 1st person to 3rd person, one of the possible bad endings was the player becoming a cenobite.
The concept for the game sounds like it was ambitious (if strangely fourth wall breaking), what few screenshots and shown off assets exist look pretty, and it was to feature some voice acting and FMV footage of Doug Bradley himself as Pinhead, recorded this during downtime from shooting Hellraiser Bloodlines.
The devs could never cope with the engine (be that for having too ambitious of a vision, or if they ran into the kind of problems Blood's devs did trying to get technical support from Ken Silverman), and in spite of having supposedly like +90% of the assets done, they think the game is shitty and unsalvageable, so they cancel it.

A couple of screenshots of empty levels were shown, some map layouts, and apparently some sprites and textures were shown at some point, in .jpeg form. I think this game was much further along, and probably had at least a somewhat playable build.

>>9558271
Here's a good article about this:
https://andrewyoderdesign.blog/2019/08/04/the-door-problem-of-combat-design/
Definitely read it despite what I'm about to say, but you will never fully solve this issue. I just fired up Plutonia's first map, pic related. I have zero reason to venture outside of this hallway. I will likely die if I go out to take on the chaingunners without the safety net of retreating further into the hall. I think you should just do what you feel you need to do if you have some kind of arena in mind. Croteam will just fucking lock doors for no reason and pit you against a horde of Mental's forces and it's great. People get really weird about these things in Doom and Quake maps, and I get it, artifice like that shows the hand of the author, but by and large I really don't give a shit.

>>9561908
>Alpha 3 and Darkstalkers 3 don't have to load up four characters at a time.
And? My point is that these ports are ok. What's yours? We settled for much less during the 16-bit generation so having A3 and D3 at home at this quality was great. Especially since Saturn versions stayed in Japan.
>The N64 with the expansion pak has 8MB of unified RAM.
Unified RAM doesn't help when texture cache is only 4kb and bottlenecks the whole system when it has to be explicitly asked to constantly fetch new data from RAM. PS1 texture cache on the other hand is an associative cache so it takes no CPU cycles to be updated and VRAM size is the only limit.
In short, N64 port of a Capcom fighting game can have arcade perfect animation stored in RAM but actually displaying it at real time would stall the whole thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562198
Ok, since you guys continue to insist, let's check MK Trilogy closely.
First of all, MK games have simplistic backgrounds with many tiling and repeating elements. Compare this with CPS2 games that have more big and unique, sometimes animates objects in their backgrounds.
Next, the chatacters animations. MK Trilogy sprites are very thin and don't have much unique animations. SF Alpha games are kind of simple too but Darkstalkers and Marvel vs games have more elaborate attack animations that take a large chunk of screen (and VRAM). MK Trilogy being this lightweight on animations is pretty much confirmed by the PS1 version: it easily holds 4 unique characters for 2 on 2 combat in PS1 RAM - when one character is defeated the game doesn't stop to load the second one from the disc. No Capcom game manages to have four complete and unique characters in a single fight on PS1 because they take much more memory than Mortal Kombat ones.
N64 has more RAM and doesn't have to deal with loading from the disk at all, so it allows SIX unique characters in 3 on 3 combat. Great, right? But here's the deal: the animation quality is worse than in PS1 version. So while there are six characters in N64 RAM, even having only two of them on screen, N64 can't animate them as fast as PS1 version. This is barely a cart size issue - adding a couple of frames to each character standing idle animation would make them look a whole lot smoother and this takes a very little space of ROM. MKT ROM has a enough of padding (aka unused space) for this. Even without using the unused space they could just remove that fancy MK logo in flames title screen and shitty looking MK1 stages and add better animation instead. But they didn't because N64 can't run it as smooth anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562805
There are certainly no 1800 sprites in Mario Kart. It makes a heavy use of composed sprites, aka sprites made from separate elements. Car is animated separately, wheels are animated separately and superimposed over thr car sprite. And then finally the chracter sprite is added on top. Using dynamic palettes for car colors you may "construct" unique sprites for every racer. The sprites themselves are very nicely and smoothly animated but they are very small in size. And finally, the game doesn't run at 60 fps. It runs at 30 and it's enough to fetch needed data from VRAM to buffer. A 2D fighting game at 30 fps would be a big downgrade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562805
>N64 could use the cart rom chip like RAM and stream data much faster than any optical media console on the market
And just to add to this, no cart based system actually does this. It still has to use RAM or different caches in between. The question is how fast can it fetch the data? Not to mention that many N64 games had to use compressed graphics so the system had to take the data from the cart, then uncompress it to RAM and only then it could use it. It wasn't free.
The system that operates very similar to what you describe is Neo Geo. I don't remember exact details but SNK didn't bother with ROM sizes and memory costs and used the biggest ones available because they could sell the carts at a big cost anyway. And then NG architecture allowed them to stream the graphics from ROM to RAM almost for free. N64 was built with different strengths in mind (fast 3D scene calculations) and it wasn't optimized to toss large sprites around with the same ease.

N64 version has 28 characters but only 22 unique idle animations. So in the end you have to add only 44 new sprites to the game. MKT rom has around 1Mb of unused space which is more than enough for this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So CPS2 games use frame skipping to enable their turbo modes. The higher turbo mode the more frames are skipped.
But instead you could do this in reverse. You can run the gameplay logic at 60 fps internally while only displaying 50 fps sprite updates but stretching out the time the frame is on screen to make the gameplay speed still the "normal" speed*. This won't have much of an effect on the visual appearance of the game because sprites are often held on screen for multiple frames anyway so rarely will an important frame get skipped. It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**

There were other tricks used in the PS1 ports that should work here. Changing the hit sparks to 3d graphics is the first thing. The life bars could also be 3d. That's a little bit of memory savings. I think you could probably do something for the in-game timer to make it out of 3d graphics as well. Not numbers but maybe something like a two colored wheel that runs out.

*Tournament players would cry about the slowness but it is what it is.
**This would make occasional differences to the gameplay by having a move be one or two more frames of animation longer on screen resulting in something that would usually be safe on block to be punishable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Also I think it is important to remember her that although the game engine of these CPS2 games run in 60 fps the graphics do not often change at that speed. The various moves the characters do have animations that last per sprite frame on screen for multiple display refreshes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563421
Of course it could be ported but at what cost? People around here are acting like PS1 SF Alpha 3 is literally unplayable.
>An XVSF64 that was released with
>>nearly static backgrounds
I'd rather go for 3d backgrounds. Small textures take less memory than full 2b backgrounds and N64 has enough juice to push polygons. KI Gold style. A bit less detailed than MvsC2 but still good enough on CRT.
>>many cut frames of animation
Yes
>>1 second loads between character swaps
No. N64 RAM has enough space to fit 4 characters, especially with cut down animations. Since you would have to fetch data only on swap It would lead to some slowdown or dropped frames at exactly that moment but barely noticeable overall
>>incorrect resolution compared to arcade
This would actually help because horizontally squished sprites take less memory
>>blurriness
N64 bilinear filter halves the texture cache. Switching it off would be a better idea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563240
The information you describe is totally wrong.
Most cart consoles have memory-mapped ROM with RAM-like access timing. Sprite streaming is a common practice. Its easy to see it in Mario Kart Super Circuit, for example, by opening a VRAM viewer or tweaking the ROM timing in an emulator.
The Neo Geo outright used ROM for sprites instead of RAM, not even needing streaming. NES also usually functioned this way, though the cart could decide to use RAM instead. (CHR ROM/CHR RAM)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563751
IP owners inevitably become out of touch over time.
To get into high positions in established companies of any kind, it is usually the case that you need to have a long and successful career in the business market. The higher ups are then either older men who worked themselves up over time or rich middle aged men who simply bought the company. It so happens that the older a company brand becomes the more out of touch with the consumer demand they become. The, for this problem specifically hired, market analyzing team only amplifies the whole process, as they have in most cases only raw numbers and data to go after. By chasing and misinterpreting raw data, they further distance themselves to the actual realistic customer demand that they had initially fulfilled. That is usually the case for any product oriented company with a fairly successful early stage growth rate.

My personal approach is to determine in a franchise, when and where the cracking points for passion and quality starts to substantially influence and negatively impact the end products. Then I simply ignore their mere existence in relation to the whole franchise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

No. It’s the gp2x the successor to the gp32 the first handheld emulation machine ever made, shit for brains. Both of these consoles were huge in the home brew scene and sparked the handheld emulation scene we have today. I’m dead serious. Gamepark split up after making the gp32, which caused the gp2x to be made, but the teams were competing with each other which eventually led to the pyra and the gpd win to be the competitors. That was the beginning of the hand held computer and handheld emulation machine fad that we see now. It all stems from the massive home brew scene on the gp32 and gp2x. It doesn’t get you very far being a dumb faggot, but now you know.

- weird dual stick placement
- can install Android and all the associated benefits and games

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This boss is so ridiculously hard without magic even with save state practice. Your attack is insanely slow, your hitbox is massive, the fireballs and boss hitbox are massive, the fireballs fly all around the screen constantly hitting you over and over and knocking you back, and you do absolutely pisspoor damage considering you need to jump up twice to even get a single hit in. Even if he had half his health and you had double your health, this fight would STILL be extremely fucking difficult with no magic and harder than vast majority of NES bosses.

How the FUCK did anyone ever beat him without save states? Did they all just abuse the spin slash? Did they just use some broken strategy they read in a guide or heard from a friend? I couldn't imagine going through multiple stages with every fucking death just to get another 5 second attempt before dying.

It's literally one of the hardest bosses I've ever seen in my life (if not the hardest) and puts Contra, Castlevania, Mega Man, Ghosts N Goblins, TMNT, etc. to shame. It's the most insane difficult spike I've ever seen, because the rest of the game is hard but fair, but I'm not even exaggerating when I say this one boss alone is like 20x harder than the rest of the game combined.

posts.com:
- CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

> Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
perhaps true for graphics cards and monitors, but that is the fault of the graphics card, not the CRT.
an NTSC signal directly drives the electron beam. it don't get no faster than that. video game consoles used a technique called "double strike" to get 240p instead of 480i, essentially sending an invalid NTSC signal to get the beam to draw the same lines instead of alternating. hence those scanny ass scanlines.
> CRTs cannot have touchscreens
they sure as fuck did, and they existed since the early 80s. they were common on ATM machines.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExKowj2g8N8
> CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
fuck yeah they do =)
seriously be careful if you decide to fuck around inside of one.

>an NTSC signal directly drives the electron beam
ACKSHUALLY, it's not true. What directly drives the electron beam(s) is an RGB signal. NTSC or PAL composite signals have to be decoded into RGB + sync first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550859
It's functionally identical to an F-type connector that you typically associate with RF input. It's the same signal just shaped differently.

Any RF box will do. Or actually, you don't even need a box; the purpose of that box was so that you could hook up your console without having to give up access to your TV channels. But since analogue TV isn't a thing anymore, it's a moot point. For instance you can just hook a Nintendo or Atari straight into the coax port without a box and it'll work just fine (actually better since less chance of interference from a shitty box)

If you have an s-video port then you don't need a s-video to scart adapter. The problem with those HDMI converters (and anything else that calls itself a converter/scaler) is that you'll have a bit of input lag and also your output will be 480i instead of 240p. Meaning the image will bounce and you won't get scanlines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558619
completely normal, especially for the top and bottom. its called overscan. you'll notice most old games don't have status bar information in the very top and bottom of the screen because of this reason.
a little bit is fine and normal: about 8 pixels or one square in any direction. just center it the best you can.
FCEUX by default cuts off the top and bottom 8 pixels of the screen by default, it was assumed TVs just were this way.
WARNING: you don't want to go crazy adjusting it either: if you make it perfect for your NES, your SNES and PlayStation will be out of whack, etc etc. analog signals were never perfect.

i took some pics to compare 16:9 mode anamorphic widescreen vs letterboxing.
i don't have any /vr/ games that do anamorphic widescreen, 240p or 480i, so here's a wiiu setting screen, connected to an sd flat screen tube (it needs some adjustment) that does 16:9 mode. the wiiu is here set to output 480i onto a 4:3 screen, which it automatically letterboxes. the result is that the picture is displayed in 360 horizontal lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: and here's the same screen but with the wiiu set to output 480i anamorphic widescreen, and the tv set to 16:9 mode. this shrinks the vertical deflection so all 480 horizontal lines are used to display the picture. all wiiu examples are over component

posts.com: here's a close-up of star fox zero's title screen letterboxed. i don't know if the wiiu internally renders at 360 or renders at higher and then downscales.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: and the same but in 16:9 mode. as for how it looks in person, the flicker is less in 16:9 mode, and the "scanlines" (black spaces) aren't as apparent. interlacing artifacts (because it's one frame per field, not sure what the terminology is) also seem to be less apparent in 16:9 mode, but i don't know why that would be. as far as picture quality goes, the difference didn't seem that big. noticeable only if you're looking for it. i'd say see for yourself if you have the option.

>>9563724
you might live in an area where there just aren't many crts, but here are some more options:
-check your listings daily for several months, including curb alerts, garage/yard sales (if such things exist where you live), and estate sales
-create a wanted/buying listing on craigslist
-expand your search area and do a road trip
-ask your friends and relatives if they have any laying around
-see if you can't get any from a local recycling facility, including any organizations that accept electronic donations for reuse
-thrift stores, although some don't accept crts anymore
-flea markets and swap meets
if all that fails or if it's easier, you could pay ebay price and hope the seller packages it properly

There are indie arcade developers out there. They've released their games in arcades. There are actually a good amount of them if you do your research.

Your best bet would be to make the game and cabinet, and then approach a independent arcade owner and see if they are interested in your business proposal of putting your game in their arcade. Then you can split the profits if people like it.

>>9563675
>It's not so much the making of the cabinets that I'm interested in but the making of games.
Then look into the Polycade. Its an arcade cabinet system that plays Steam games, PC games and has their own game store. It's an arcade cabinet for use in arcades. Arcade businesses buy the cabinet and choose what games their want on it.

You would have to figure out the details of working with Polycade and getting featured on their platform. But it's definitely an option if you don't want to build the cab yourself.

I think there are few companies that do something similar to Polycade as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563675
>I'm interested in but the making of games
Selling digital arcade games won't get you far either, sadly. The younger audience doesn't jump onto arcade focused game design anymore, unless it has a fundamental rogue-like element to it.

My honest advise is, that you focus your time making steam games, but with different main objectives than just high score as the main objective. Classic shmups or beatemups won't get you far nowadays.

If you want to be successful try: story focus, rogue-like or rogue-lite focus, focus on sprite art or focus on retro parodies in combination with either sprites or story.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9561439
metacritic really is not a good indicator of how liked a game was, it's gotten a lot better in recent times since game critics are most honest than they used to be but most game reviews from before the internet came from gaming magazines which were mostly just advertisements. No game coming from a major franchise for a major company was getting anything less than a stellar review, because these publications weren't going to review a game poorly when they were running an ad for that game 5 pages later. Even well after the internet blew up there were several prominent examples of this where a game that was hated by fans got great reviews, Dragon Age 2 and FF13 immediately come to mind - I know those aren't retro but its a lot harder to find evidence for this for retro games since archives of pre-2000 forums aren't the easiest to find.

I would say it's actually the opposite, where what you read online about a game is a lot more accurate than the review score.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: DKC123 are tight platformers and are still god-tier today. DK64 is a tech demo. Once the awe of it being a 3D game wore off people realized it's barely anything as a game. Super Mario 64 and Crash Bandicoot are more universally appealing because they still maintained tight platforming in 3D, whereas DK64 does not have that. The best you can say about DK64 is related to the music, graphics, and cinematics, for a game in 1999, which I still believe is far less appealing than the original trilogy (and Banjo-Kazooie, which was made by the creators of the original trilogy). The best DK game on the N64 by far is Diddy Kong Racing, and I won't listen to anyone who says otherwise. Even the director of the DK64 said it was bad in 2004, deal with it.

>>9555159
It's possible to force your switch to use the 1.0.0 version of Atari 50 that has Warbirds still in it. The issue is, you need to do a factory reset on your switch. As long as you've let a physical game update, you can't run that game ever in the future without having at least that update. There's some sort of data that remains after you delete data that tells the switch you NEED to update before you can play. Factory reset is the only way to clear that data. Factory reset your switch, then take it offline and put the cartridge in and install the game and disable auto-updates for that game, then your switch should have Atari 50 with Warbirds and can be safely taken back online.
I know your anger, I felt it the day I brought home a PS2 and MGS3 Substance and was all excited to play Metal Gear Online, only to find out they shut the servers down a few months prior.

>>9556962
>This could effect all games on all consoles btw. What's to stop them from sending updates like this to all other collections or standalones? The future looks grim.

It's actually much worse than that. When it becomes sufficiently practical, and eventually it will, mainstream single-player games will not only be online-only but streaming-only. The general public will embrace the convenience of paying a subscription to access all the games in a provider's library, without having to worry about disk space, let alone shelf space. This all-you-can-play model will take the edge off how they don't actually *own* anything in that library, whose contents are subject to change without notice.

There will be nothing for us to back up, unpatch, crack, pirate, or preserve, because all the code and assets will be out of reach on some corporate cloud server. You will have no recourse when they change a game, retire it, or revoke your access for whatever reason.

No matter how digitally locked down they are, movies, music, and ebooks can at least be recorded through the analog hole (i.e. filming the screen), but games will be at the absolute mercy of rightsholders.

t. Cassandra

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560002
The Lynx has a custom 16 bit 16Mhz CMOS handling the sprites and rendering the graphics, and a 4Mhz 65C02 (clocked faster than the SNES CPU) handling the general game logic. It also has a dedicated math ASIC that could transform the sprites quickly or something like that. Not even the SNES or Genesis could match the Lynx's performance, let alone the 7800. It's a low res amiga on steroids.

posts.name: Anonymous

I dunno why people call it the videogames crash of 1983-1985 or 1984. Consoles and arcades were in a decline starting in 1980. Computer gaming was on the rise during the same period. All thanks to the new cheap micro-computers like the Apple II, Atari ST, C64, etc. Computer gaming hit a slump in 1985 until 1988-89 when VGA started getting widespread and not just cutting edge. Consoles hit a slump themselves in 1993 and didn't recover until 1996, and arcades were going down in profits during the same time. Never hear anyone talk about the computer videogames crash of 1985-1988 or the videogames crash of 1993-1996.
The only difference is there was a major recession in the early 1980's. So somehow the recession-related cutback on customer spending is a major videogames crash event, but all the other times the industry has seen their market get cut in half is business as normal. And Nintendo is somehow the savior of videogames for launching the NES at the start of an economic boom period. Never hear anyone say Sid Meier, Jordan Mechner, or Al Lowe saved computer gaming for the growth in PC gaming in 1989.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The dynamic of the entire game is completely different now.

When I played the PS1 version way back when the overall idea for every encounter was to really put effort into paying attention which unit can tank what and who is exposed and how to protect them. It truly is/was a tactical game since attack options were limited and most units were very squishy.

In the new one everyone is more or less tanky and with all the cards popping up everywhere and charging up your special moves it's essentially a game of outflashing the opponent in an all-out brawl.
I wouldn't say it's a bad thing, but it's a different type of combat altogether.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I like the changes. Played the psx version years ago and have the psp one but couldn''t get into it on such a small screen. I'm not real keen on the voices, but I play with the sound off, and am glad they are an option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562863
I've not played the original, but I've been playing the remake and I don't think the level cap or lack of random encounters is a problem. The cards are weird, I don't think they really detract from the gameplay but I'm not keen on how RNG they are, and they're a little too abstract for me. I mean obviously the combat isn't very realistic and that's fine, but when characters fight with weapons or magic even if it's not realistic you can still accept it as a part of the world, whereas these cards are totally abstract game mechanics that don't correspond to anything within the narrative. I also think that when characters have mid-battle conversations that are supposed to be serious, all the little cards scattered around undermine it a bit and make it look silly. It's not THAT big a deal, but still.

Anyway, maybe it was different in the older versions or maybe not, but I've played up to midway through chapter 2 (chaos route) and it doesn't feel that tactical to be honest. Most battles I just smash my dudes into the other dudes and don't have to pay that much attention to come out on top, even if the squishier party members get targeted they aren't too squishy and I can get someone to revive them so it doesn't really matter. I feel like I could've won about half the storyline battles by just leaving the computer in charge of my units and walking away from the screen. I don't like mechanics that let you undo turns so I haven't used the one in this game, and the only problem it's caused is making recruiting enemy units more annoying since they're pretty hard to persuade and my guest party members keep killing them. Speaking of which I've never liked Matsuno's obsession with AI-controlled party members and wish they'd've included an option to control them manually. The other thing that's annoying is the game doesn't list what equipment each class can use anywhere and leaves half the status effects a mystery as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558641
A lot of them would be looking at pretty niche audiences because many of them are too hard for most players today (partially because they were designed with the intent of trying to get people to pay out more money to continue playing). You could maybe have a set of 'retro cabinets' with certain sets of controls or features as to allow you to play certain genres of old classic arcade games, and some fightan game ones, I guess essentially MAME cabinets, but these would not have a very strong draw with most audiences today, hell, they were already waning in the late 80s as home gaming kept getting better.

What you need is gaming experiences which aren't easily played at home. Sidescrollers and fighting games with nice graphics are easily available either with ports or rereleases, modern substitutes, or piracy. Instead you need to focus on more advanced experiences, like lightgun shooting games (something which is essentially dead with modern systems), certain kinds of VR gaming, DDR, and then games with special motorized physical cabinets where the player interacts with or is housed in a large prop, like Afterburner or some of those racers.

The only people today who are going to go to an arcade to play the kind of games they can easily play at home are going to be enthusiasts of these things or people with a nostalgia for old ones. Pong caught on because that was something people couldn't get elsewhere, and as home games became a thing and got more advanced, arcades kept developing, they didn't resign themselves to making a prettier Pong, which is more or less how arcades went in the 90s and 2000s.

If it isn't novel, there's no draw.

posts.sub: How would you rank the Crazy Taxi games?
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: more content isn't better when it isn't sharpened to the same pointed edge that the arcade game was. it was designed to earn money by keeping games short, but you can nonetheless keep games going for a very long time through skilled play. neither crazy taxi 2 nor crazy taxi 3 were designed this way; 2's jumping was a nice idea but the maps just weren't designed as sensibly as 1's loop was to properly utilize it, and it's too easy to keep a single run going for an nauseatingly long time with no challenge involved. crazy taxi 3 just throws intelligent level design out the window entirely in favor of whatever the fuck you'd call its version of the ct1 map. the games just got less thoughtful with each release; crazy taxi 1 was a sum of its parts and adapting its pick-up-and-drop-off passengers game loop to another game doesn't work 1:1

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9552965
>Not sure what your priorities are, though

Mostly challenging "footsies". My favorite thing in Castlevania tends to be nailing those high commitment whips and jumps against relatively dynamic and unpredictable baddies.

Second most important being just good platforming making use of those tense high commitment jumps.

Castlevania 4 is generally just a bit too easy. Feels like the stages weren't really designed around the 8 way whipping and changeable jump arcs, since there's so many times where you can easily whip enemies from the floor below or before they can even attack you, and the platforming rarely puts too much pressure on you.

Hell I remember picking it up for the first time in ten years (with almost no memory of any of the stage layouts and bosses) and making it up to the final boss rush without a game over. That's kind of how pushover the game is. Combine that with how loooooooong it is and it can start to feel kind of monotonous in a single sitting playthrough despite how nice the art and music is.

I don't hate it but I like it mostly for the atmosphere and nostalgia. I think I'd put it below 1, 3 ,Bloodlines, x68, and Rondo in terms of level design and mechanics.

>Hagane

The fuck are you talking about.

Hagane is easy as shit comapred to almost every Castlevania outside of 4 and Rondo. I'ts a great game but it's not comparable to Castlevania at all since it's much less methodical and has a much more acrobatic moveset, you can attack while moving, etc. it's an entirely different style of gameplay.

>You just described old games

No. Castlevania has a particular style and particular style of challenges. It's not better or worse, it's it's own thing which has its own particular pleasures.

If you don't like buying your jumps and attacks a wedding ring, they're not for you. But if you do it's a blast. Personally I love 'em all (except Dracula XX)

> it's the only one where I need pixel perfect jumps to a point

I don't remember almost any jumps that felt pixel perfect, though there are certainly some jumps like that in Castlevania 3.

What makes action-platforming hard (in a fun way) isn't pixel perfect or strictly timed jumps anyway. It's putting interesting pressure and challenges and multitasking on you while your platforming. CV4 doesn't really do that.

Anyway I'm not going to get into a pixel by pixel autism level design comparison but running through the entire series almost fresh, all of them gave me satisfying challenges except 4 (and Rondo, but Rondo it was less of a big deal because it's shorter and had more fun stuff going on).

>>9553141
>You said Hagane

I've 1cc'd a lot of shmups and old games over time. I only really recorded or uploaded the ones I considered particularly challenging. Hagane I thought was an easier clear and took me very little time to do, so I didn't bother recording it.

I don't know why you think that one is a crown jewel of difficulty, I've never heard anyone hold that up on retro forums as particularly challenging. I guess the second loop where everything has super extra HP is harder

>No it's not and 99% of people agree, which is why games evolved the way they did

Even if it were true that consensus means better, that's really not true. There are tons of enduring franchises (including modern, still running ones) that are built around strategic limitations.

Dark Souls for example is pretty much just OG Classicvania combat in 3d. You have non-cancellable attack animations that are not instant and can't be moved during, mobility options which are very limited and set your trajectory in stone for a very specific location, etc.

Or then there's the enduring popularity of many horror games and action-horror games built around strategically limited controls. Resident Evil 2 Remake may have done away with tank controls, but it still put harsh limitations on players movement and dodging options and it was applauded for it. The same could be said of Dead Space 1 and 2 which are absurdly popular and are more or less based on the same very rigid control limitations of RE4-5 and Remake 2, just applied to a more high adrenaline action game.

Making it so you can move and attack at the same time or change the trajectory of mobility moves isn't better or worse (or even more popular are less). It's a design decision that enforces different styles of play.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553073
>cant kill Shaft
Grab the Bible from the breakable wall before the boss rush, it makes every boss easier but especially Shaft because you can use it to knock away his fireballs. For the lightning orbs, admittedly that's kind of a crapshoot but if they start drifting away from each other you want to be between them, towards each other you need to backflip away from both of them ASAP. For his third attack, try to backflip over the orbs when they come towards you. It's tough but doable.

As for Dracula phase 1, grab the cross at the start of the level. Whenever Dracula shows up, toss a cross at his face and then backflip over his fireballs. It might take some time to get a good feel for how far from him you have to be, but once you get the timing down he's completely toothless. Also, he'll do the magma ball attack on his 4th teleport first, then on every 5th teleport after that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560982
The PAL version of FFX isn't anything extraordinary. The squished screen and slow speed is just how every PAL conversion was when devs did not care; there are many, many, many such cases.

The reason early PS2 games like FFX and Onimusha were shat on for their 50hz only PAL version is because Europeans and other PAL regions had just tasted the Dreamcast.

Sega enforced a policy on Dreamcast: games HAD to provide both a 50 and 60hz option. So now people (and reviewers) knew, and could easily test the difference, and anything that didn't provide a 60hz option, like early PS2 games like FFX, were shat on for it (rightfully).

This ending up scaring the average publisher, as if even Squaresoft's Final Fantasy and Capcom aren't immune to being shat by reviewers for this, nobody was safe; and 60hz options on other consoles became more and more widespread.

Well finding out what the good ones are is not hard. Racketboy is a good website and youtube has good "hidden gems" "essentials" list for just about every format. If it looks like it's made by a passionate gamer its going to be a good list. If it looks like it's click farm its going to be questionable. You can find 90% of the good games on a given format very easily this way.

As for the reasons why. Well that's a tall order. Most of the reviews written in the past were really just trying to give you enough info so you could decide if you wanted to buy it while pointing out some obvious issues in hopes the dev would read them.

Take that tiny pool of players who are experts in the genre: they can play them at a high level and have played them all. Ok, well among that group you need someone who has the second talent of being very good at introspection, why he likes one more then another, and he needs enough communication skill to be able to put it in writing in the way the rest of us will get it.

Yes those types of reviews exist but they are scattered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558489
>Like what made certain side scrollers good compared to the bad ones
Aesthetics and difficulty. Streets of Rage 2 had fantastic sound design (not just the music) and a few different difficulty levels, none of which were made bullshit just to suck quarters out of you because it was designed as a console game. Most belt scrollers suck because they're all about finding that one thing you do to beat every enemy and finding the One Weird Trick you use to beat each boss. The problem is that none of these tricks were ever intended so they're almost never fun. In the original Final Fight you beat most stuff by doing a little jab infinite, and the original Streets of Rage is basically the same thing. 2 actually gave you a bunch of different options for dealing with normal enemies, different grabs you could do, its weird vaulting mechanic they expanded on for 2, and for the most part they toned down jabs on higher difficulties.

Street Fighter 2 got a bunch of different versions because World Warriors was a glitchy mess released with 4 characters you could fight against but not play as. They had a lot to expand on so they did.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562614
It's a lot more realistic than Resident Evil games. Inventory is counted in weight and not slot, you can drop items anywhere and pick them up again, items can be thrown to damage enemies, most of the weapons are melee weapons and the guns only have about 30 bullets to be found in the entire game, shotgun shells get wet when exposed to water, and melee combat has 4 different moves that determine reach, speed, and blocking. Most of the puzzles are investigative rather than puzzle-y, half of the enemies can only be beaten by solving puzzles, and if you don't enjoy reading you will miss a huge chunk of the game's enjoyment.

One last thing that makes this game different from RE is it isn't scared or ashamed of fail states. This game is a chaotic hell and wrong steps will kill you with no way to stop your death. You can lose key items and not be able to progress. You can save and load anywhere, and you should be glad of that because the difficulty would be insane without it. It's a pretty hardcore game that will intimidate the mainstream Japanese console survival horror players. The only reason RE didn't straight up copy this game is the designers had to water down the difficulty.

>What's the best way to play it today?
Just get a gog copy. Or set it up by yourself in dosbox, don't clock the CPU too high or you won't be able to sprint.
>With smoothest controls?
Don't mind the controls, they're really simple, but it's going to be a rocky ride ahead. You'll get used to it eventually.

They didn't copy it because the game is full of awful design. Not that I blame the dev, they had an incredibly small team and the game is extremely impressive for its time. Its for sure worth a playthrough. But the game itself is clunky and frustrating, the camera angles are incredibly confusing and sometimes orientation and depth is hard to perceive.

Resident Evil built on its concepts, yea they neutered some cool stuff like the melee combat. Alone in the Dark also has puzzles that blow RE out of water.

But RE lasts to this day because it is a refined experience. It has less concepts, because the game is more focused on doing what it does well, rather than overloading the game with all sorts of mechanics that scarcely have a use. It is the rough diamond of the survival horror legacy.

>When searching about it I find a lot of claims that it's the first survival horror game (as not, not just the first 3D one) which is simply untrue.
It's the most influential one, but far from the first. Normalfags tend to attribute the most influential games in the genres to be the first ones, like Wolfenstein 3d.
>Sweet Home was a survival horror game and that released in 1989.
There are many older ones, and it's not real time action like most survival games are. It's often cited as the first survival horror because it inspired RE, but this older PC88/PC Engine game resembles the Resident Evil series far more than Sweet Home does: https://retroconsoles.fandom.com/wiki/Shiryou_Sensen:_War_of_the_Dead

I would consider Maxwell Manor (1984) as the first true survival horror game, and Project Firestart (1989) to be the first modern conventional survival horror with elements that are found in almost every modern survival horror game.

Regarding AITD4. Virtually all versions of it (PS1, PS2, Dreamcast) have annoyingly long load times between camera angles.
Go for a GOG version on PC, it's backgrounds are very high quality, loading is instantaneous and it has fully remappable gamepad support.

If for whatever reason you absolutely need to go with a console, go with a ps1 version.

It's a very competent RE clone with some differences - puzzles are harder, text files are long as shit and they kill pacing of the game a little bit, two scenarios differ a lot compared to RE standards (one is more combat heavy, the other more puzzle-heavy), and the sole major flaw are enemies respawning. Atmosphere is gorgeous.

/v/ and /vr/ both tend to ignore this game for some reason

the feel and atmosphere of Alone in the Dark is that of a great Call of Cthulhu detective/survival horror game. the fact that you're not well equipped to fight these horrors, you must read entries, run at times, and be aware of how outmatched you are, makes this a special game. it really feels like a horror game when you start to realize you can brute force your way through everything coming for you. running from room to room to avoid a creature is very much a horror theme thats missing in games. I think a lot of players are upset because your characters are not very strong and they miss the point of the game. the horror in it is not because of big monsters and zombies, but because the unspeakable creatures and mystery that surrounds you. I played it at around your age as well its still a unique game that is overlooked because 'muh resident evil'

AitD is a mess, it has certain mechanics such as item weight exists just for one puzzle, it has useless items simply junk that was left by devs without any awareness of how it might confuse the player. AitD doesn't have "more gameplay", it has inconsistent ideas instead of gameplay.

>>9563554
i think it's fine, i mean the way scenario progression for the rct2 scenarios works is already quite different to how vanilla rct2 did it and infact is the cause of the weird difficulty curve of rct2
in vanilla rct2 you could just pick any scenario and there was no unlocking at all, and the expansion scenarios + any custom scenarios you had were all lumped together into a massive mess
and openrct2 already changed this years ago by implementing a more rct1 style approach where they're sorted by source games with an unlocking system. so what you're probably thinking is "vanilla" really is just how openrct2 handled it before.
plus if you really want a more rct2 accurate "progression" system then you can just disable scenario unlocking or just switch to difficulty based scenario sorting which is more like vanilla rct2 but without all of the messy organization

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How do you go about completing the video games you play? Do you always stop when the credits roll or are you one of those that loves to collect everything? Are your own preferences regarding this always the same or do they vary depending on how much you've enjoyed the experience up until that point? Do you dedicate completion only for a few selected titles or do you go for it more often than not? I feel that it'd be interesting to see everyone's approaches to this sort of thing, as it's something that kept getting more and more common with each passing console generation, and nowadays it's everywhere, with things like trophies and achievements being quite common to see.

Have you ever deliberately gone for a 100% run before?
What 100% completion are you the most happy with getting?
What was the most difficult 100% you've ever gotten?
Did you ever give up because you couldn't pull it off?

When it comes to this last question, there's another thing that's on my mind... did you ever get 99% completion in something, as in there's only a single thing missing for it to be 100% completed, but you couldn't do that last thing? Wheter it's an item you couldn't find, or a mission you couldn't beat, or a bug within the code that never got properly fixed, etc. If you've ever faced this situation before, either a single time or more, what was your approach? Did you try to force it as much as possible even if it stopped being enjoyable or did you move on from it in a positive way? I usually manage to pull it off, but I won't lie that there have been a few cases in which I couldn't manage it at all.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9563697
Completionism is fundamentally a simple bait from the developer to artificially and unsubstantially increase your playtime without having to add any realistic content or material whatsoever.

Yes, I personally play most games exclusively for the story, unless they are fighting games or shmups, etc. However, when I play games where it happens to seem that developers placed expectations in their audience to complete achievements or gather collectables of some sort, it quickly come across as rather insulting to me. As an belittling act towards their customers and end consumers with an low effort, easy and silencing practice to keep those busy that want to be kept so. Therefore I happen to associate completionism with superficiality, credulity and mental weakness in others.

No, I did never ever do a 100% run of any kind in any game, because that is simply not worth my time.

I just finished the illusion of gaia, and while it was a enjoyable game, why did it feel so shittily made? I've heard this trilogy get wanked hard an while soul blazer was an amazing game, IoG just felt odd. There was very little cohesion between story and gameplay. And even in the gameplay, which was decent there were blatant errors. Such as one of the dark power abilities being completely useless (I'm referring to Freedian's earthquake, which can only be used when jumping down and stuns enemies for a long time. I wonder whether there were some sort of production issues, because this is only one of the many blatant errors in this game, which definitly makes it worse than Soul blazer. Haven't played terranigma yet. Opinions on Illusion of gaia?

posts.com:
It's the weakest of the main 4. (ActRaiser, Blader, Gaia, Tenchi Souzou)

Still has a lot of striking audiovisual moments for '93. But I agree that it's an uneven game.

Keep in mind that these games were made in quick succession unlike anything that happens today. They made:

ActRaiser
Soul Blazer
ActRaiser 2
Illusion of Gaia
Robotrek
Terranigma

All in the span of 5 years. The glut around '93 was overkill and bled into production deadlines/budget. ActRaiser 2 was likely not a planned game but asked for by Enix USA (and to remove the SIM elements) because it had been a hit in the West.

It's why I love it, and why it's my favorite Quintet game. I really love Illusion of Gaia and it's the one game I really wish there was a retranslation of, as I feel like something was lost in it.
Quintet managed to pull off a very specific mood that almost no other company ever did. A certain somberness, a game focused on harsh realities in some specific way.

Finding the wild animals in the zoo, and the goat eating her dead husband in Terranigma also are like this. The Inca Ship of Gold in IoG is a good one too. The animal kingdom in Soul Blazer. The invention of music to mourn their dead in ActRaiser.

posts.com: this thread clearing up my weird memories concerning illusion of gaia convinced me to give it a replay and man, this is actually really, really good, better than when I was a kid. it's just all so strange, I feel like it's unintentional but it ends up feeling like a sequence of dreamy vignettes, and the ramshackle-ass translation contributes perfectly to the surreal quality. the whole sequence on the raft with your health ticking down feels very ahead of its time. I really have a thing for messy games so I'm very biased but I'm thinking this is actually an extremely solid little underrated title.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't blame them for -trying-.

But it's obvious that Dreamcast and Shenmue both share a lot of the same fundamental failings. The Dreamcast was essentially built as a final struggle against Sony's PS1 (and rumored PS2) by making something that was much more advanced, and more expensive. Audiences just didn't click with it, and Sega were left with an expensive failure that quickly got superseded. The same is basically true with Shenmue. Shenmue could've worked if it was a legit system-seller like GTA or Halo, but it wasn't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The realization that Sega could not compete with media giants like sony, microsoft and nintendo on hardware space, and it was the correct call.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: They needed a killer app to sell the console. Didn't work but it's always a gamble.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553232
Audiences definitely clicked with it, the DC was a massive success at first. The truth is that the PS2 was going to sweep the floor with everyone, not even Nintendo could dream to compete with the massive install base of the PS1 and the massive hype surrounding the PS2. And even though both the GC and the Xbox had excellent games and superior hardware, neither stood a chance either way. Even being weaker hardware-wise wasn't even that big of a deal for the DC as consoles in Japan have extraordinarily long life spans, both the Neo Geo AES and the SNES received games well into the late 90s. In fact, Sega could've absolutely kept supporting the DC for its lifespan (even the PS1 received games that the DC never did like THPS3), but they were so used to being a top contender that it would've been too demoralizing.

>>9553212
It was a gamble that didn't pay off, BUT people put too much emphasis on it making back the budget alone.
A lot of money was spent on tech as well IIRC, and that (as well as experience of making these types of games) was carried over into future projects too.
So yes it looks particularly bad on paper (and in reality was definitely not a success) but there's more to it. Not to mention the idea wasn't to make the money back in one or two games, but to launch a franchise, so they intended to take a loss on the early games in the hope it would be a 'Final Fantasy' series for them. Shame it didn't pan out, Shenmue 1 and 2 were really cool. 3 got some things right, but mostly didn't live up to the previous games.
I think the Dreamcast would have been finished regardless though.

It's not hard to see the comparisons, especially once encounters become much more frequent in Shenmue 2. They are both ostensibly beat em ups with a wide variety of activities to perform in the overworld. Shenmue does not have nearly as much fighting and has problem solving and conversations in its place. Yakuza is much more bound by genre convention as it released later, a more straightforward mashup of beat em up and RPG rather than the vague structure of Shenmue. They have totally different priorities and atmosphere, but there are things in common.

No they couldn't. After the Sega Saturn, Sega wasn't in a good financial position. They invested so much money in the Saturn and barely made their money back. Sega Saturn was a big failure outside of Asia. Unlike Nintendo, Sega sells their systems at a loss. Sega makes money on game sales.

Sega honestly didn't have the cash reserves to do a launch of another console like they did for Genesis and Saturn. So Dreamcast was financed by Sega going into debt.

Sega literally used a "Credit Card" to pay for the Dreamcast. Sega ran out of money (they hit their credit card limit) around 2001. That's why they discontinued the Dreamcast. Japanese banks would not give Sega anymore loans or extend Sega's credit. They were already DEEP in the red and owed a lot of debt.

The Dreamcast did not sell like they had hoped. Sega gambled by paying for the Dreamcast with loans and credit. And it failed after 2 years.

Sega was going to declare bankruptcy if it wasn't for the Sega Miracle saving them.

>>9551524
Having played and finishing both the PSX and the PSP versions, I'd say PSX with a few mods.

First of all, grab Final Fantasy Tactics: The Lion War and apply it to the base game:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12767.0

This adds all of the stuff from the PSP release into the PSX version, save for:
1. An additional character Luso (he's from Final Fantasy Tactics A2 on the DS, but lore-wise doesn't make any sense for him to be in the game anyway) who got replaced by Ashley Riot from Vagrant Story (another game set in the Ivalice region, also on PSX, in terms of the setting this is the latest entry timeline-wise) - but he's been done really tastefully.
2. One character class (Onion Knight), which kinda sucked anyway and was a major pain in the ass to master.
3. The updated translation, it sticks to the straight to the point, no bullshit script of the PSX release as opposed to going all Shakespearean on your ass. Some people will love it, others will hate it - there's two crowds of FFT fans, plenty of arguments have been made for both translations over the years.

So that's what you'd miss out on. But holy fuck do you get so much more, with Continue+ and NG+ options, three additional endgame characters you can recruit (demons) after you've finished the game for the first time, additional skills, being able to change the difficulty, stat resetting option once you've reached level 99 with a character (won't take long, trust) and would like to improve your builds, fuckloads of quality of life little patches etc. Can't go back to the vanilla FFT after this, PSX or PSP, this mod rocks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9551524
PS1 version modded with the extra stuff the PSP version added is the best of both worlds. The reason to not use the PSP version itself is because the translation was shit and done by someone who did not understand Matsuno's writing. The original game's very blunt, matter-of-fact way of talking is in fact how the characters talk in Japanese, they don't act like they're in a stage production. Also it ran like absolute shit on an actual psp and it took like a decade for PPSSPP to come into existence, so the only way you could get it running well was by playing a modded ISO which is a non-issue now but you can just play the PS1 version.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9552687
...once you get your PSX FFT disc image patched with The Lion War, I'd also recommend downloading a patch that replaces the PSX movie clips with the anime-like ones from the PSP release:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12945.0

Also makes the transition from the intro sequence to the start menu much smoother. So overall deffo grab it.

And then there's another patch you could consider, which adds further quality of life fixes to the game, but this one's a bit of a bitch because it could potentially introduce some bugs that weren't present in The Lion War mod originally:
https://ffhacktics.com/smf/index.php?topic=12769.0

As an example, I've had one fight constantly crashing the game in DuckStation (emulator I'm using) no matter what. I reloaded the save file before the battle using an ISO with just The Lion War mod + movie patch, finished it no problems, saved and then continued playing with the ISO that also has them QoL fixed without further crashes, but because of this I'm not sure whether I should recommend it.

As an example it allows you to send special characters (like Cloud, who someone mentioned already) on missions/errands and boost their skills that way, which is a mad fast way of going about it without grinding for hours - normally that's something you could only do with "generic" characters. And that's great, that's the real juicy bit here really, but again, not nearly as heavily tested as The Lion War and there could be bugs, full disclosure.

If you'll have trouble patching, I can upload the disc image for you in a few hours probably, but you'd have to link me to some sort of a free file uploading platform because honestly I've no clue what the fuck people use nowadays.

>>9554775
Now for some extreme cope and education about an iconic line which was altered heavily in the PSP Translation.
They changed the layout of the scene for the PSP version entirely.
Originally Delita delivers the iconic line as he looks back towards Agrias who was trying to stop him. The PSP version has him direct the line towards the princess herself since Agrias wasn't even in the same vicinity as him until shortly after the line was spoken.
https://youtu.be/ghYPElytjpY?t=13
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DpQX9vxjjIM
Therefore, there was a significant change in this line's intent between versions which, in my opinion, causes the more curt "blame yourself or god" to seem much more convincing than if he'd said the more flowery line to Agrias before running off.
The opposite holds true for the PSP version, where it seems to make considerably more sense for him to say "Tis your birth and faith that wrong you, not I."
tl;dr neither version is incorrect, and it's entirely down to the precise context of the given version of the game.

>>9561139
There are two ways to go about this what worked for me using pcsxe I think will also work with

Method 1: Select analogue controller as a controller type
Connect a wheel and configure it in a way that turn left/right is on left/right analog stick and throttle/brake is on bound to the up and down on analog stick. In games usually left stick is used for turning and right for accelerating and breaking.

This method has some flaws since many games have input acceleration and deadzones for controllers and to counter it you will need to set up negative deadzones and other cope outs.

Method 2:
Select NecGon as an controller type and bind your wheel turning/throttle/brake to corresponding axis.

This method is much better since necgon have same analog input for turning, brake and throttle and in games like Gran Turismo you dont get killer deadzones.
Another major benefit is that games that did not support analogue steering initially such as Ridge Racer/Rage Racer and Wipeout 1 (and maybe 2) had support for NecGon so you can play those games with analogue input, even if you bind Your DS4/Duallsense input to NecGon axises you will get analog control in those games that is often better than selecting Duallshock as your controller type since games often had enabled input filters and large deadzones for DS.

That is at least how I go about it with PS, never tried this on other emus but I think Method 1 would work universally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've done it with retroarch. The one pain is making sure your wheel is one device, because RA mapping is dogshit and doesn't support multiple devices. My wheel is 3 devices, a high end DIY DD wheelbase, DIY pedals, and a cheap logitech shifter. I use a combo of HidHide and Joystick gremlin to hide the 3 controllers and merge them into a new one, then map them to NeGcon. It can be fiddly setting the buttons right because RA is retarded when it comes to mapping names, you'll probably need a new profile for every new game because the mapping changes.

The main issue is that you're not going to get any FFB, at least not from consoles. RR4 had a form of FFB for the Jogcon, but the decomp effort hasn't cracked it yet, and might never do so. The game plays well with a basic centering effect anyway, I had a lot of fun. For arcade stuff, you'll have a much better time although the FFB plugin can take some tweaking. 6th gen you can get FFB emulation for both PS2 and GC, I haven't tried Xbox.

PS1 and Saturn should both be fine, you can emulate the Arcade racer for Saturn and it works with almost every racing game. One thing to bear in mind is that you'll want a very low steering range, both the NeGcon and arcade racer are set to 180 degrees and I think 270. Too much steering and you'll be moving way too much, these games expect you to hit full lock on most turns. N64 I don't know about.

DingDongwhatchi?.. just more cookie-cutter, boring "shots-everywhere" junk to BORE me to TEARS, sorry. Last one of these new games I tried was Ikaraga... Sorry! but I learned to play color-matching games when I was two, don't need to do it anymore! Deleted THAT computer application from my Dell desktop after about 20 minutes.

R-Type, Gradius, Darius... those classics are a little more up MY alley. No TINY hitboxes to make the game look harder than it is, no half-naked japanimation cartoon girls, no gimmicky scoring to cover up the total lack of any real substance... just a little thing called good old-fashioned GAMEPLAY that seems to be forgotten nowadays... yep, I love all the super-duper powerups, and checkpoints.. yes recovery is HARD but not IMPOSSIBLE. You actually have to put in a little elbow grease to get your strength back! Something the little ones today could stand to learn from, if you ask me! They seem to want games where you can kill everything on the screen with one button press, right after inserting a coin! Instant gratification with no challenge. And personally, I usually prefer a "side-view" kind of shooter compared to a "bird's eye view" one, all those obstacles give levels a lot more personality, not such a common thing when every me-too game wants to look and play the same.

Me, I've been playing a lot of R-Type part two lately. I can only clear a couple of boards on my first man right now. I may wear out my joystick before I can manage my one quarter win! But I don't quit! What can I say, I prefer a little hard work to getting a free handout! Playing some Wings of Wor on my Sega too, and Biohazard Battle. Great vintage stuff!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561476
>And less than 50 were built.

1993 was pre-internet so information is not available on the exact amount. However my research confirms around 25 to 30 Ridge Racer Full Scale Units were exported for Western/Foreign markets. They were spread across the USA, UK, Spain, France, Middle East, Australia, etc.

And around 20 Ridge Racer Full Scale were used in Asian markets. Namco themselves kept several units in reserve to use in their Namco branded theme parks and Namco arcades in Japan. Several independent arcade owners in Asia had a Ridge Racer Full Scale too. A few malls had them as well. In the 1990s, any business owner could buy it from Namco if they had the money.

Trust me. Namco would NOT invest money in a factory, put Ads in sales magazines (for arcade owners), make sales flyers, and only make a small handful of Ridge Racer Full Scale Units. You need bulk sales to make it worth the investment.
