Different anon here. I actually had the chance to purchase a Ridge Racer Full Scale 20 years ago. The owner was closing his arcade and offered to sell it to me. But the guy wanted $15K. At most I could maybe $8K and the owner wouldn't come down in price.

Most home consoles looked far better than Ridge Racer Full Scale in terms of graphics. The arcade market had also crashed and many arcades were shutting down. Xbox live and online play had killed arcades.

I'm wondering if I made a mistake passing on this machine considering only a small amount were made and it seems no one else in the whole world saved their Ridge Racer Full Scale machines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few years ago I spent hours A/B testing my Wii against a Toaster NES. I fucking LOVE the NES so this is not a Zoomer opinion. There are two parts to the story. The TL;DR is that besides the slightly off scaling (that I wasn’t able to match) and a color palette that was a lot brighter (in a good way) I didn’t find any issues … UNTIL I SOLD MY NES.

Seems like I found all the problems once the hardware NES was gone. IN GENERAL, I don’t think you will be aware of it, however in some games (like Super C) the camera on the diagonal climbs in level one didn’t work properly. I remember finding other issues with some games (slow down, stuttering) but it wasn’t game breaking.

In short, keep your NES but use the Wii for convenience. Input lag wasn’t a huge issue on a CRT (you can use a wired controller too you casual).

SNES obviously doesn’t work perfect. Contrary to what anon said earlier in this thread, Starfox 2 doesn’t run correctly. Maybe it’s my rom but it was a bit weird when I tried it years back. Also, YOSHIS ISLAND is a meme test game, THE SNES TEST GAME IS MARIO RPG.

Mario RPG will skull fuck an emulator. And the wii SNES emulator does not run Mario RPG, HOWEVER most games are fine/perfect enough.

GBA runs like trash if you use VBAnext but MGBA seems to run every game at full speed, I never encountered any issues but I’ve only tried a couple of games. What didn’t work in VBANEXT worked in mGBA.

I played snatcher on the wii genesis emulator and I remember at some point I had to switch to another cause it was starting to lock up.

The Wii is perfect for gaming. Emulation accuracy is good enough for $50, native CRT support, massive library. Also as other anons point out the virtual console ports seem to remedy accuracy issues.

>Wii
Wii/GC
>PS3
PS1,PS2,PS3,PSP, EMULATION UP TO CPS3
>XBOX OG
XBOX OG GAMES
>PC/LAPTOP
Everything in between

^^^ This is the winning strategy.

Can I ask which emulator you used last? The latest builds for snes and nes are FCEUltraRX and Snes9xRX.

I grew up with Super C and didn’t recognize a problem with vertical scrolling when I tried it right now. Scrolling was always weird with the little white boarder on top even with real hardware. I did see definite graphical problems with the Cheetahmen intro for Action 52 and some possible gameplay bugs but that whole fucking game is a glitch so it’s hard to say if something is going wrong. I’ve heard others say Action 52 is the hardest NES game to emulate but it’s hard to agree when the game isn’t an official release.

I’ve been emulating since the Dingoo days so I know how Super Mario RPG was the holy grail of emulation for a long time. Tried it right now and found no obvious issues with stuttering or the menus. If you aren’t using Snes9xRX then you have to try Starfox 2. The nintendo logo has a tiny bit of stuttering but everything else plays great. Maybe it has some frame skip but the game overall is so choppy it’s hard to tell what’s intentional.

I’m not saying it’s perfect. On Mega Man X2 there’s a 1/4 second hiccup right before the intro miniboss fight. And in Sim Earth the intro sequence is rough. What I am saying is that I’m sure all these games can be played to completion, all the heavy hitters play great, I haven’t seen any games that just won’t load at all and that’s all a huge accomplishment.

>>9561163
A lot of the early pioneering emulators were made either by edgy hacker/demoscene types or enterprising but boring old nerdy programmers. The former, however, would eventually get bored or simply move on to other things in life, while the latter were more likely to view them as products and would often monetize them. It wasn't until later, once the generation that actually grew up with the consoles from childhood, that the hobbyists and obsessive autismal types took over, which simultaneously led to massive improvements (with ample help from much higher computing power, of course) but also gave the scene the stink of constant autistic shitfits it's known for today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562017
DK64 is fully playable, though it does have something of an issue where physics don't work precisely as they do in real hardware due to the fact that it was programmed to accelerate your character's movement proportional to the amount of lag, so the more the game lags, the more momentum your character picks up. Due to inaccurate timings, almost all N64 emulators run the game too well with fewer framerate drops, which on paper and for the purposes of regular intended gameplay is a good thing, but it means you don't get the movement boosts you'd normally get when the game lags. This only matters if you're trying to pull off certain glitches and sequence breaks, though. It also leads to characters in the title screen demo gameplay not moving quite as expected and perhaps on certain cutscenes, but that's even more minor. Some older builds of simple64 replicated the slowdowns more accurately than every other emulator, but the latest releases regressed on this front at some point.

An 8bit console by Sega. Has some interesting features over the competitors, like more colors and vibrancy and some fun games.
>was it ever a competitor to the nes, like mega drive was to snes?
Technically yes but in practice no. To compete with the NES it wasn't enough to sell decently, or even good. You would have to sell astronomical amounts of stock. The Master System only ever sold decently.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Master System port of R-Type was the first videogame I owned. Here in my small town in Scotland, I'd say the kids I knew were divided roughly 50/50 between owning a Master System or a NES. I played Zelda 1 and SMB 2 at a friend's house, and while I did enjoy them, they didn't fill me with envy or make me regret my Master System. I did have a Game Boy, however, and when the 16-bit consoles came around I opted for a SNES, perhaps because I always, even at a very early age, had a powerful instinctive aversion to Sonic and his gay little universe.

>>9562602

The game itself is Sega Rally in disguise. Or at least, the Saturn version of Sega Rally. This port was made by AM3, who also did Virtua Fighter Remix. AM3 also did the Sega Rally port, and used the Sega Rally game engine for the development of Daytona USA CE. It shows in the physics and car handling. It does run at 30fps, unlike Daytona USA which only runs at 20. CE does have better draw distances, and does run at a slightly higher resolution. It does have two player split screen, and additional tracks.

>How does HL2 stack against 1?
It's been a while since I played either game, but I remember liking them both a lot. They do very different things, however.
HL2 is definitely much more... setpiecey? than the first game. That isn't to say that the level design is bad, it's just much more linear from how I remember Half-Life's being. I don't really remember the level design being very conducive to doing a lot of exploration.
I really liked all of the weapons in HL2 though, really dug the art design, and since I played it when it was still relatively new (when the Orange Box released) I was also really into the in-engine cutscenes. I liked Episode 1 and 2 a lot, too.
The story isn't going to knock you off your feet and some of the physics "puzzles" might make you roll your eyes, but I think the game is a must-play if you already played Half-Life.

>What are the best standalone/sp mods?
I wish I had an answer for this, but the only mods I ever played were multiplayer. Had shitloads of fun with Zombie Panic and Age of Chivalry back then.

For HL1? My personal picks would be:

Sweet Half-Life
Poke646 + It's sequel Vendetta
Azure Sheep
Point of View (AS and POV cross over with each other's main characters and are connected as mods)
They Hunger
Visitors
USS Darkstar
Afraid of Monsters Director's Cut
Cry of Fear
HL:Zombie Edition
Echoes
Residual Life + Residual Point
Absolute Redemption
INVASION (French, you can select English subtitles from an .exe that's inside the mod folder)
Someplace Else (From the creator of MINERVA, a HL2 Mod)
Paranoia (Find the standalone version that's working off of Xash3D, the HL1 Mod version requires a modified Opengl.dll which WILL trigger VAC if you connect to anything multiplayer, including non Half-Life games like CS 1.6, TFC, DOD:S, etc. Because they're in the 'Half-Life' folder rather than their own standalone folder)

>>9561485
>>9561573
HL2 is largely guys with machineguns and then also some zombies and headcrabs, featuring a section with antlions, and the occasional aircraft battles, it works overall, but considering how much more variety there was in HL1, it feels like they underdeliver somewhat. The aircraft fights in HL2 are pretty good, and they're expanded on from the sequel, but the CPs and grunts having only those goofy APCs and none of the variety of tanks and artillery from HL1, nor a fraction of machinegun nests or traps, makes them a lot less menacing and interesting, and there's no equivalent to the assassins. There's the Striders, but they're not as tough as they ought to have been (and occasionally they pretend I don't exist and leave the map).

D3 has its own problems with enemies, like an over reliance on surprise closets and teleports, many of the enemies not looking as dissimilar as they should ('gnarly grey skinned humanoid' describes too many of them at a glance), and how you're very seldom fighting anywhere BUT dim gray steel rooms and corridors (shades of Wolf3D here), but they still have old champs like Revenants, Chaingunners, Fatsos, even the Archie, and these are still pretty versatile and varied. Then add stuff like the little spiders, how Imps now leap at you and can climb at places, Zombies with chainsaws, and the Bruisers in the expansion. There's also a variety of different bosses, some which I think are a lot better than most of HL2's boss encounters (Guardian is probably iD's best boss fight).

I like both a lot, but I think there's shortcomings, more could have been learned from their predecessors, and there's outright things which one does that I wish the other also did.

>sell below cost
Not that much. The 3DO was sold for profit and it was still significantly cheaper than the PCs with similar performance of its time. By the end of the 90s, the PS1 and N64 production cost was so cheap they could sell those systems for a fraction of their launch price without losing much money.

It wasn't always like this. In the mid 80s, you'd get a much better deal getting a C64 for $150 than buying the NES. That was before IBM killed the whole low end computer gaming industry for good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few reasons, OP. Similar reasons as today but more stark then.
If you bought a PC you bought
-the hard drive
-the motherboard
-the Pentium chip
-a modem
-a soundcard
-CD ROM
Basically you bought... a personal computer, which you used to get onto AOL and download pr0n or at least the local news and fun websites from AltaVista. Also, emails. Also also all the novels and short stories you were writing in WordPerfect or WordStar or Apache OpenOffice or whatever.
You didn't just game on a PC.
Some of the cost-difference could be mitigated. You could go cheap and build your own PC from all the assembled products.
If your time was valuable: Gateway had a nice niche basically assembling this shit for you, not charging too much to do it. Failing that there were smaller businesses which would do this.

>>9562651
Popular home computing was fairly new so it was it pretty easy to swindle new customers. Most computer nerds knew that you could assemble a computer at least half as cheap as those name brands. Try telling some boomer at the time that you can get something half as cheap by going to a small computer shop and they will stick their noses up "waaah, but I want IBM".
A year later that computer would be massively cheaper, no one forced you to get the latest computer. I also had a voodoo 2 and it was a lot weaker than the dreamcast.

I was a teen back then so the idea of paying $150 extra for a console that was 10 times as powerful was a big decision to make for people at the time. Nowdays spending a week or 2 pay to get double the performance is no big deal for.
It was actually weird reading about dreamcast, my reaction at first was why would anyone need such a powerful new system, the old ones are fine.

>>9558343
>early PS3/XBOX 360 games are in need of a proper LCD shader, since the very first generation of consumer flat-screen TVs have a vastly different picture than modern TVs.
While it makes sense for "preservation" purposes those TV were terrible. There was hardly any true 720p TVs. 768p or 1080p was the standard. As a result those TV would upscale the image using different algorithms with terrible results. It would be great to mess around with them but they looked much worse.

I grew up with Ariel: The Little Mermaid for my SEGA Genesis, and while I could never beat it as a kid, I still went back to it from time to time, there was just something about it that captivated me. I did give it another shot many years later, after finally getting into emulation and replaying the classics I grew up with, which I hand't played in years due to my console not working anymore, and while it didn't impress me, and I actually found it to be quite clunky, I went through the effort of beating it on the hardest setting with both Ariel and King Triton, it was fun, as basic as everything in it actually is. What I struggle with the most is how Ariel/King Triton controls, as it feels like the water is pushing them constantly, it doesn't feel responsive or fluid whatsoever, regardless of how it might be realistic in a way, I also feel the hit boxes needed some work, Ariel/King Triton's attack needed to be more effective, and they desperately needed more invincibility frames... the 1st and especially the 3rd level are both fun, and the reason I go back to this sometimes, the problem is in the 2nd and 4 level, which can both be a chore due to the shortcomings I've mentioned here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters (GB/1998) is one of my favorite video games of all time, and one that I've played more than anybody ever should considering how little depth it actually has, and how ludicrous some decisions by Konami regarding its design were. A few things got me into this, the 1st is that an English translation came out in the last few years and gave me a chance to finally play it, this was the most crucial reason by far, because otherwise I'd have never even attempted to play it, the other reason is that this is historic for the Yu-Gi-Oh! OCG and TCG, since it essentially gave Konami the license for it and was used as the basis for the original rulesets. A lot of things about it are ridiculous, for example, do you want to get a Blue-Eyes White Dragon? Simple, just beat Kaiba... a 100 times, do you want a Red-Eyes B. Dragon? Simple, just beat Joey... a 100 times. You do get a card every 10 wins for each duelist, but the best ones require 100 wins... and I did it for about 5 or 6 of them, to get the cards I wanted, why? Well, this is the closest that we'll ever get to a Duelist Kingdom RPG, and it was my favorite arc, so its won me over for that reason alone, and kept me playing. Also, the artwork is incredible for the hardware and resolution.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9551447
I have a pretty lengthy list...
>Sonic 3D Blast
Saturn version is pretty good, it's a flawed experiment but I find it intriguing
>Three Stooges on the NES
I love the show and this game had a really interesting development, plus it's not bad as a mini-game collection.
>Jaws on the NES
When evaluated as an arcade style game with a map, it's pretty fun.
>Nightmare on Elm Street on the NES
4 player option? Solid platforming? Interesting concepts taken form the third movie? I'm thinking it's based.
>Dynowarz on the NES
Brilliant concept, solid game play needs more love.
>Mighty Bomb Jack on the NES
Pretty dense and addictive once you get the hang of the controls.
>Top Gun on the NES
So what if you suck at landing, this one is pretty relaxing and fairly impressive for its time.
>Double Dragon V on the Genesis
The Saturday Morning Watchmen of video games, pretty funny and encapsulates the 90s well.
>Techno Cop on the Genesis
Awful game play, bland presentation, but once the silence kicks in and you are gunning down thugs, it gets eerie. It feels like your playing through the last scene in Taxi Driver meets Laser Blast.
>Shaq Fu on Sega Genesis
The Black Belt Jones of video games is here, horrible concept but the art direction and presentation is top-notch. Game play is ehh but it is playable.
>Generations Lost on the Genesis
Flashback and X-Men rip-off with homoerotic cover art, still an oddly fascinating game with a fun Bionic Commando style grappling hook. Intriguing development history to say the least.
>Pit-Fighter on the Genesis/Arcade
Awful SNES port aside, Pit Fighter is prime slop, it's a cocaine fueled nightmare that deserves praise for the tone.
>Mr. Nutz on SNES/Genesis
Not a complicated game, but it has so much soul I can't help but love it and admire the craftsmanship that went into it. Also there were only like 3 people working on this under-budget oddity.

>>9562596
I printed some sega saturn buttons and they were alright but a bit bumpy. The main thing I made is a power conditioner plastic box. Its just a circuit that takes the typical centre negative plug and outputs to centre positive, I added a capacitor to reduce interference and a diode so I don't accidentally plug in the wrong type of power. It also has a voltage display so I know whats going into the systems. Spent way longer on it than I thought for a simple box and could use another revision since dimensions may not be printed precisely. There are some gameboy cartridges on thingi verse you can try too. I'd like to also try 3d scanning but the results I've seen have been a bit meh.

Atari were always most comfortable in the arcade style and could never really adjust when games started to get deeper.

An element of that is the fact that they never seemed to understand how integral decent music and sound are to the home gaming experience so they always treated it as an afterthought. The 7800 used the same sound chip as the 2600. The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800. Even on the Jag, stuff like the soundtrack in Tempest 2000 was the exception. Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.

>The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800
It had an 8 bit 4-channel DAC which could be switched into PSG mode. It could sound nearly as nice as the SNES sound chip provided you gave it good samples. Most Lynx games use the PSG sound mode, perhaps to save some ROM. But in DAC mode, it sounds great.

>Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.

>>9560056
Probably, although the anons saying the C64 is much more susceptible to voltage/power issues nuking the various chips are definitely correct. The original PSUs are literal timebombs. When I picked one up out of a thrift shop back in 2018 I ran it just long enough to confirm it could boot and that the 1541 was functional, and even that was a potential risk. If nothing else with these a modern replacement PSU is essential

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560340
In fact a bad PSU will blow up the RAM before it harms any other components in the computer. The RAM chips have small, dense dies and are very easily damaged by overvoltage while the main chips like VIC-II et al have relatively large, coarse dies that can take a fair bit of abuse. So the RAM is basically like a crumple zone in a car frame; it will get toasted first and provide a warning of imminent PSU failure.

If you happen to find a C64 with bad RAM it's more often than not a PSU fault and an indication that you'd better throw that PSU away at once (occasionally you'll come across a machine with Micron RAM chips which do a fine job of self-destructing with no help needed).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562815
in fact the very earliest 6502s from 1975-76 were 8 um. over time MOS managed to shrink this some. the VIC-II as anon said was 5 um but also had substantially more transistors than a 6502. by the time C64 was in development, they had two main production lines running. the first was the NMOS line that couldn't do anything smaller than 5 um. there was another line that did 3 um HMOS. the large process nodes that VIC-II and SID used were outdated by the time Reagan was president but they were there and there was no point in not using them as the production line was there and the VIC-II and SID wouldn't benefit from die shrink as much as a CPU or RAM. also MOS had years of experience with the older large node NMOS process and the initial production run of VIC-II/SID in 1982 got something like 80% yields. by the time they'd moved to the plastic-shelled R2 VIC-II in early '83 it would have been better than 95% yields.

during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.

yes those large node processes were outdated, but since Commodore only made chips for in-house use and didn't have to be concerned with consumer demand as Intel and Motorola did, they didn't necessarily need to be aggressive about adopting the latest tech.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563087
VIC II had 13,000 transistors. TED had something like 20,000 because it has to do all graphics functions plus RAM refresh plus I/O plus sound.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562890
CMOS was always better but in the early days ran really slowly. It took a while to figure out that you could speed it up by thinning the dopant layer (at the expense of making the chip more vulnerable to overvoltage).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Most people know of the top down/isometric action adventure games buried deep within console libraries, but I never see anyone talking about PC games other than LBA and maybe Dink Smallwood.
Of the top of my head, I can only remember two good ones, Al-Qadim: The Genie's Curse and Entomorph: Plague of the Darkfall.
Al-Qadim is pretty straight forward with a nice setting. It has a few classic arabian nights set pieces to get the adventure going, all very simple stuff but it works well to make the game feel bigger than it is. It is a bit stiff, but definetly playable.
Entomorph is a pretty similar to it in structure and gameplay (they both remind me more of Dink Smallwood than Zelda), but has a weirder setting. It is all about insects. The enemies are insects, most of the characters you meet too and as the game goes, you become more and more insect-like. The game has a lot of very memorable moments, I played this a long time ago and I still remember a lot of its subplots. You meet a spider that oversees that fabric of space and time, infiltrate a beehive and learn to mind control insects that are too stupid to resist your mind tricks. The biggest problem is that the game is filled with bugs (ha). I remember getting soflocked at least once.
If you know any other good ones, please share.

Legacy of Darkness with Reinhardt is legit one of my fav N64 games. KCE Kobe really laid down the ideal blueprint for 3D Castlevania despite its troubled development, the PS2 games got rid of everything that made their work ambitious and interesting.

It came out exactly two months after OoT and still runs way better than it. LoD in low res mode in particular is one smooth motherfucker.

Castlevania 64 is unique, even with all the "Zelda 64 inspirations". KCE Kobe did experiment with it a lot, which is exactly why it wasn't "intuitive" to play. Heck, the character movement and animation in CV64 is actually ahead of most games from the era. And the level design is for the most part fantastic, matching each locale architecturally.

Plus the superb soundtrack and sound design, of course.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550794
Start with Mario, Sonic, Kirby, Donkey Kong Country, Mega Man (X or Classic is fine, but the latter tends to be harder). For Genesis there's Ristar, Dynamite Headdy, Gunstar Heroes, Vectorman, Rocket Knight series, Monster World IV, Popful Mail (technically an RPG but uses platformer controls), and The Terminator (SEGA CD version of course). Finally on TurboGrafx you've got the Bonk games and the Valis series. Some people like Castlevania but I find the early games to be kind of brutal, barring Super Castlevania IV.

For 3D platformers it's down to Mario, Banjo, Sonic, and Crash for the most part. People seem to like Jak, Sly, and Ratchet (more of a TPS/platformer hybrid) but I personally never really played those. Honestly there's so many good platformers on Super Nintendo alone you probably won't get bored with it for ages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few people recommend playing Sonic at some point, and I'd agree. Sonic 3 is especially short and gives you an "easy mode" by letting you fly as Tails. (Not technically retro, but Sonic Mania also does something similar, and can be a bit more forgiving in places.)
But something to keep in mind: Sonic has a few arcade sensibilities. Sonic 1/2 have no saving, sometimes you need quick reactions to enemy placement, getting all the emeralds is hard and there are multiple routes so it encourages replays. Most big-name platformers in the years following will lean a litle closer to Mario in their structure. So if you try Sonic and find some bits aren't to your liking, don't let it put you off platformers.

The Kirby games are also tailor-made for beginners, while still usually having an enjoyable difficulty curve. Kirby's Dream Land on GB is very easy; and Kirby Super Star has an even easier, shortened remake of it with better graphics as a "first world". Adventure is also

>>9551193
https://www.mariowiki.com/Super_Mario_All-Stars has a list of all of them.

In all of them, the biggest changes are graphics/music, and the ability to save after each world.
Super Mario Bros. 3 gives you a few extra lives to start off, some very minor layout changes, and it lets you run and throw fireballs at the same time.
The Lost Levels has some more extensive changes to make it easier (saves after every level, extra lives on World 9, making access to worlds A-D easier), but it's still the hardest and cheapest game in the collection (and I think the Mario series as a whole).

Haven't played the International version in a while but the Japanese one is really hard, especially during the last couple of worlds. The only difference is the hit system but it's a damn big difference, you basically have one less hitpoint
SMB1 has no continues (yes, yes I know, don't mention it, it doesn't count, that shit is cheating) and you have to learn how the game works and get good to beat it without warps, it takes hours of practice if you've never played it before
Then we have SMB2J which is by far the toughest NES platformer out of all non-shovelware titles and I'll die on that hill
SM USA/International SMB2 is the only 'easy' Mario game on the system and even then, it has limited continues and you'll definitely get booted back to the title screen a couple times if you are new to platformers

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Kirby games were literally built from the ground up to be easy Platformers for newcomers to get into the genre. If you've never played any games in this style before then this series is the best place to start. Don't listen to anyone suggesting NES games (aside from Kirby) those titles are simpler than later entries but the difficulty is brutal in comparison. Save NES titles for when you feel comfortable enough with the basics that you can handle a challenge.

The games many of you are recommending are excellent, but OP specifically asked for easy games to start with and if they take your suggestions they may get turned off to the genre.

Donkey Kong on whatever system. Game Boy Donkey Kong is a remake and is great.
Mario Bros. with a friend. GBA version is one of the best releases to start with.
Super Mario Bros. 'till completing easy mode.
Super Mario World.
Super Mario 64.

Sonic 1 Master System.
Sonic 2 Genesis.

Metroid.
Metroid II.
Super Metroid.

Don't play kiddy stuff like Kirby. If you need easier than what I've recommended, start with NSMB on the DS, or any New Super Mario on any system.

Also, Hollow Knight is the current best modern platformer, and Super Metroid is the best all-time, but those are harder because they are nonlinear. Start with the linear action challenges like Mario before doing maze platformers (commonly called Metroid 'vanias in honor of also the Castlevania series, which you should also play the first of on the NES).

Finally, and generally: play and make romhacks.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9553550
>Sonic might be a little bit more of a platformer, but in the sense of actually having to calculate and time jumps to avoid enemies or traps, they're not in the same league as other platformers.

Two things about this:
1. The primary complaint people have with Sonic games is that there are TOO MANY obstacles. Jumping is the only tool that Sonic has to avoid these.
2. Sonic levels have tiered level designs centered around verticality based branching. What this means is that jumps are actually so important to the experience that if you fuck them up you go to a totally different, slower part of the level.

Now let's look at a random section of adventure island: https://youtu.be/v_C-Yql7bHg?t=1216
Totally flat terrain. No branching or variance of the gameplay based on platforming skill. Corridor style level design. Sonic is more of a platformer than Adventure Island and I'd love to have you tell me otherwise. Goddamn you're a retard.

What was your first experience playing Doom?
>late 1994 sunday afternoon
>7yr old me, obsessed with Mortal Kombat 2
>don't read gaming magazines, out of the loop about PC games in general
>dad brings home a big box with cool artwork and floppies inside
>"drop your nintendo, anon, I've got something here"
>"nooo dad, not your simulators again"
>(I actually loved playing F117 with him but all I wanted to play at the moment was Mortal Kombat 2)
>"It's a shooter game like contra but it's in first person like you are watching the action with your own eyes, anon"
>"yeah dad, like in your simulators. This is a really stupid idea"
>dad switches on the PC. I don't like it much because "Super Nintendo has cooler games" and I'm always afraid to break it somehow. I am not allowed to switch it on and use it on my own
>Windows 3.1 starts but dad shuts it down to "free the memory"
>starts a blue-windowed shell instead
>I am looking at the game box while the game installs. It says Doom II
>some of my classmates were joking about Doom when the lights went flickering in the class. Never seen the game myself and never knew that there are two of them
>after the setup process the game is launched, first level starts, I see pic related
>"huh, these stairs look cool"
>dad moves around, shoots
>"definitely cool"
>I ask to try myself and for the rest of the session it's just me playing and dad watching me play and giving advice
>we finish the game a couple of weeks later. Keyboard only, frequently getting scared and lost in the levels, save scumming
>It's the best gaming experience in my life, thanks dad.

I preordered via phone to ID based on some screenshots in magazines which did not even have any lighting/shading model and the joy I had with Wolfenstein 3D. The game did not look as good to me as the well lit with better status bar betas in those screenshots. I was on a 386DX-40 so performance was bad, practically unplayable without switching to lower res and reducing the screen playable area. I stuck with Wolfenstein 3D for the performance reasons, but still managed to play though on those low settings. Unlike how it seems to be played by all others, perhaps I did not like it as much since I took it more cautiously trying not to waste the resources on the ground (small health at 10 damage, large for 25, and I would save the items that boost over 100% to collect in backtracking after everything was dead). I guess this was the reason I am not as impressed with the genre like others, but that's my odd taste in games yet I still think it is a very good game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560493
For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993 and have about half left over (people didn't do this at the time). Doom only needed a 486 to run well, which hovered at around $1000 at the time, and would keep dropping. By the time Doom 2 was in stores, a 486 computer with a mouse and the memory to use it together with the game would be WELL under the $1000 mark. Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two, with the original game's first episode being widely available dirt cheap, or even for free. Most people probably experienced it this way, many using the 386 or even 486 at their school, university, or workplace.
That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

To conclude, your dad should have pulled out, because clearly he couldn't afford to raise you if the prospect of playing Doom was prohibitively expensive. You must have grown up somewhere incredibly poor and undeveloped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561281
>For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993
You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
>Doom only needed a 486 to run well
With basic ass 486DX-33, you needed to set the quality to minimum and reduce the window size by 25% or less to get a comfortable framerate.
>which hovered at around $1000 at the time
More like $2000 for the basic ass 486DX-33. Even a shitty 386DX would be well over $1000. A bare minimum spec PC with 486DX2 66MHz, the minimum CPU for running Doom comfortably, would run you up for almost $2500. 486SX was choppy as hell and with 486DX you needed to scale down the screen size by something like 25% and set the quality down to minimum, but it will still get choppy when the game throws more enemies at you. Not sure if using more RAM than the minimum spec of 4MB will help the game run better, I suppose it does at higher quality and resolution.
>Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two
More like in half or less.
>That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.
Just not Doom, it was one of the most demanding games back then. You'd have much better luck playing it on atari jaguar.

No kidding, lol. Knew a guy who grew up on a farm in the Midwest, he scored a pirated copy of Ultimate Doom for cheap to play on his dad's computer. Him, his brother, and his dad, they really liked action movies and horror movies, but it took a bit of talking with his dad apparently because the whole hell and demon things rubbed him slightly the wrong way at a glance.

His brother made an argument about the demons from hell being your unquestionably evil enemy, and how the hero must obviously have great resolve and faith in god (in addition to his strength and training) to be able to fight hell on his own. Convincing enough apparently, because his dad grew fond of the game himself.
His dad was a movie buff, had lots of film on tape, even had laserdisc. He once showed us a Smith & Wesson Model 39 he got from his dad once upon a time, which he had put a pair of pearl or faux ivory grips on so the gun would be just like Vasquez's pistol in Aliens, which I thought was cool.
Anyway, if you couldn't even find a computer at school or a workplace by 1994 to play even the Doom shareware on, you'd have to be crazy backwater,.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561337
>You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
If you wanted the full 35fps at all times, sure, but the vast majority of people hadn't ever experienced that with a game of that graphical fidelity (compare to Ultima Underworld). The game being able to stay consistently above 20fps was already incredibly fluid for most people at the time. Compare.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=foHUXGzHOx0

Never mind that you definitely did not have to spend up to $2500. You didn't have to buy a complete pre-built, you could build your own, even reuse components from an older computer (such as the screen, keyboard, mouse, speakers), depending on what you start out with, you could even replace the 386 on the motherboard with a 486, and a weaker 486SX can be replaced with a better 486DX, the previous one can be sold off to cover expenses. You can also save a lot by skipping a CD-ROM drive, which would start at like $200 alone by 1994, Doom was available on floppies.

If you had already invested in a 386 prior, you didn't need to spend a fortune on getting decent performance with Doom, nor did you if you had a lower end 486. Some computers with 486s could also be upgraded to Pentium, which could become relevant for later games.

>>9561345
That's 1993, things would change quite quickly over 1994.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just got a CD32. I shat myself when I thought I broke the door hinge.
The CD32 has this rather heavy door hinge that is held together with a tiny little screw and a thin, plastic frame. As such it's pretty easy to break the whole thing off, like in this picture.
I was lucky. The screw had simply loosened and popped out. I was able to screw it back in, but I am now super careful with opening and closing it.
I also don't get why the power switch is on the back. Why early toploading CD consoles were made to have their power button located anywhere other than on the front is baffling. I know the original CD-i and 3DO had their power buttons on the front, but the 450/550 CD-i and FZ-10 3DO have their buttons on the sides.

AoW seems to be written in Delphi, judging from the .dpl files (they're just dlls btw).
The UI uses the Visual Component Library that is based on Win32 API but adds a lot of custom controls. Looks like it was one of the easiest way to build good looking GUIs in Windows at the time.

As for VNs from that time, maybe they used the Windows API with custom engines in C or C++ or even languages like Hot Soup Processor.
Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

posts.com: I see many mentions of games that hat their own in-game Windows-like interface, yet no mention of Transport Tycoon. Its subwindows were active references to the map in that you can build stuff not just on the main map, but any random train screen, message, anything showing a piece of terrain. It was mindblowing at the time.

>>9532823
There are several good ports. My personal favorite way to play is the M2 3D one on the 3ds. They did a phenomenal job and even fish in a given school are at different depths. I have played it emulated many times though with no issue.

I do recommend a guide if you feel stuck, there are two quests near the beginning where you rescue lost dolphins and those give you very useful abilities for the rest of the game.

Finally though, if you find yourself very stuck or the game is too hard, or you just want to play it more casually, all versions including the GBA port have the debug code which is quite robust.

You can yourself invulnerable if you want, level select or teleport to any area of the current zone. Almost more fun though is you can change the music tempo which given Ecco's incredible soundtrack makes for some really cool variations you can do.

posts.com:
>>9532972
Good luck with it, I'm glad to help! It's one of my favorite games of all time, but I understand well why it's always been a little niche. My suggestion if you try again is just take it slow for a while and learn how the game flows. The second level has an octopus that is there to help teach you. You'll feel low on air and like you should be rushing, but the octopus will slap you back of you do. In Ecco, rushing is what usually kills you. Your air is always depleting and you will think you're going to drown if you don't, but success relies on keeping calm under pressure and being accurate. Many people say it's crazy hard, but really outside of the Asterite fight and the Vortex queen at the end, it's really not that difficult ot just takes a kind of mentality that most games don't require as much.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9535508
I actually saw it from a totally different perspective, to me it was like "hmmmm never seen this kinda stuff before.."
lets not forget that most of the "sister games" back then were just Barbie crap. back then a Dolphin on the cover did not automatically give people the feeling of it being a kids game, hell the Genesis was even marketed as a console for dudebros way before the xbox360 coined that phrase.
back then most of us just didn't even feel like we could be subjected to kids games on the Genesis, Snes for sure cuz Nintendo. but Genesis just felt differently.
you saw Toejam & Earl and you didn't think "oh kiddy alien game" no you thought "wow, thats a whacky bro experience!"

Even now when I go through my rom collection and find stuff like Richard Scarry's Busytown it feels.. off somehow. as in "this shouldn't be on the Genesis"
That's just how it was marketed, even Lion King and Aladdin didn't feel like they were for kids, they were for all ages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You really have to play this game a lot to get into the gameplay groove I think. It's one of those games you must play for years to actually appreciate. I didn't think the fast swimming was very fitting with the awful puzzle block puzzle shit and enemy ambushes in corridors this game puts you through. I enjoyed the sections you have to jump and swim fast (even those infamous jumps in the library), but that's not even like 10% of the game. As soon as the game makes you push that seashell into stones in the beginning caves I knew I wasn't gonna enjoy this game. It's like threading a needle but with a jackhammer. And of course the game culminates in a horrid autoscroller full of ambushes. I beat the Machine legit twice, and the worst thing is, after you beat it, the transition to the vortex queen is very disorienting, looks like a glitch and sends you flying towards one of those alien dudes.... which can kill you in one hit before you even realize what the fuck happened. That has to be intentional.

Game shoulda have more open sections and shit, not be full of tight underwater corridors being precariously chased by non-animated crab pngs. Sounds great, looks amazing, just thinking about playing it again is giving me agitta. I was playing the M2 port and I think I gave up entirely on beating it legit during the prehistory stages, started doing savestates. Some of those are just so long and tricky and awful. Game's just not fun most of the time, I am glad I took the time to play it and know what it is but I just never want to see that fucking Asterite fight ever again lmao.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9535820
>It's not something like Space Harrier or Streets of Rage that you can play and even if it kicks your ass, still have fun with the pacing

See I guess I just don't see it that way. While I love Space Harrier to a huge degree, I also like Ecco. They are very different, but I don't see that as a bad thing. I hate this comparison being thrown around, but in many ways Ecco is like Demon's Souls was compared to other contemporary games.

From an objective standpoint there are many harder retro games, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania 3, Super Ghouls n Ghosts, Battletoads, 1ccing Gradius etc (all of which get regular threads here by people declaring that the difficulty is overstated) are all much harder than anything Ecco throws at you, even the last levels. Most games, especially platformers have similar enough controls that you tangentially get good at others while playing it. With Ecco, nothing else plays like it so you're also learning a whole new control scheme.

However, all those games have a similar flow which is much more action focused. Ecco is all about being careful, scoping out the environment with your sonar and clearing an area of enemies so when you have to rush through you can. It's very different from many other console games of the era, but I don't see that as a bad thing.

>>9536263
It's really not a handwave, it's how the game is designed. You can call it tedious, but it was never meant to be a bing bing wahoo rush to the finish type game. Unreliable just makes no sense, if you want to permakill an enemy, you can. It's about making the decision you want to.

Again as I always say in these threads, since first playing Ecco has always been in my top selection of games and I almost always have a playthrough on the go somewhere. Along with that love is the understanding it doesn't appeal to everyone, but I don't see that as a bad thing. Games should appeal to many different people.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9561779
>That's it? You just want the special move to take time to perform? An experienced player will do it as fast as just pressing b, in the end whoever practiced inputs the most will have the advantage instead of whoever uses their specials more wisely.
You're not going to see the point because you're not used to playing fighting games with another person who is able to apply enough pressure that the speed of the Shoryuken coming out actually matters. Using it as an anti-air is one thing, but doing it during the gap in a sequence of attacks, to avoid being pressured as you're getting up from the ground or as a way to knock them down immediately when they try to approach are the type of strategies special motions are meant to both limit and give more meaning to: those are all things that can be hard even for experienced players to perform when the outcome of a round hinges on it, given that fighting games tend to be very fast, and mapping the attack to a single button press, even with caveats (such as reducing i-frames) would reduce some of the complexity to the decision of doing so. More importantly, it's a way of making the game easier that also makes it more boring, and doesn't really help novice players have fun either, as it gives them less stuff to improve in and ignores the fact that they already have the option of playing in an environment where fucking up basic inputs doesn't matter nearly as much, i.e. against other beginners.
>>9561803
>So why not cut the grind? I don't care about the execution I care about the strategy
You're playing the wrong genre, then! Fighting games, much like their namesake implies, are all about emulating the exhilaration of going mano a mano with someone else, and the difficulty of executing under pressure & pulling off shit you trained for are one part of what makes the combat and strategy in them have meaning. You could always play stuff like Samsho or pick easier characters too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561959
Why? Even in platformers there are "basic moves" with somewhat complicated inputs. The triple jump in 3D Mario games is kinda hard to do at first, it requires some pretty precise timing. It's balanced around that, it's a move that lets you go very high and far so it's a little tricky to do in order to reward players who master the timing.

Then there are perfect guard mechanics seen in fighting games but also other genres like Mario RPGs and action games like Devil May Cry or Dark Souls, where you have to press the block button within around a tenth of a second of an attack hitting to parry and counter. Or delay combos in DMC where you need to leave gaps of a precise length of time between each press of the attack button to get the right combo to come out.

Lots of games gate certain moves behind execution requirements.

And the bad Conan the Barbarian game, that too.

from the wiki on it:

"Conan is an action game developed by Eastridge Technology and published by Mindscape. The game is actually a conversion of the computer game Myth: History in the Making for the Commodore 64. The game has also been mislabeled with the subtitle The Mysteries of Time, but this title does not exist neither in the game nor the manual. In this game, you play as the titular hero Conan, who must go through seven levels and brave the challenges of each level. There is also a bit of puzzle-solving required to get through each level, like acquiring a trident to kill the boss of the first level with, in which you must cut down a hanging skeleton, which triggers a demon holding the trident to appear.

The game was negatively received by critics due to its poor gameplay and graphics. The game was single-handedly programmed by Nick Eastridge, but the game was rushed in development by Mindscape, who forced Eastridge to complete the game quickly."

TLDR; it was rushed and was a conversion of a history game so the final boss is a pharoah monster.

Anon it's called investment. It's not like Ion Storm was spending Romero's money, it was spending Eidos' money. That money Eidos gave to Romero is just Romero's, he probably lost very little financially from Ion Storm failing.

Normally video game publishers are unwilling to back startups nowadays because Ion Storm isn't even unusual in how retarded and ass backwards things ended up.

>>9544364

Honestly I'm more impressed by someone being a video game programmer back in the day, even if they were shit at it, because it was a new field and not at all prestigious or lucrative.
People were coding stuff in their spare time at home and mostly dealing with how to implement ideas they randomly had or trying to reverse-engineer games they liked. Nothing was done for fame or virtue signaling.

I remember my dad used to buy these ZX81/Spectrum magazines that had entire pages of code in them. You would literally transcribe the code from the magazine and you got a playable game out of it.
Point being that there was a love and pursuit of discovery there and the entire gaming field was uncharted waters. Real pioneers.

posts.sub: Another World / Out of This World
posts.com:
How did a single frenchman in the late 80s do it? It's all ridiculously slick for its time. There's some really impressive shit here:

>animations and visual style that have aged surprisingly well
>not a word of dialog or spec of UI and yet everything the player needs to know is effortlessly communicated with environmental cues
>incredible pacing (this game makes a compelling argument for why action games should be 2 hours of perfectly paced, varied setpieces rather than bloated and repetitive 10+ hour slogs)
>camera angles and framing decades ahead of the curve
>bespoke ingame setpieces like Buddy's fake surrender or, my personal favorite, kicking a guard in the balls and running to your weapon to quickly shoot him

Fuck, it's so good. I don't think anything released afterward matches this game's level of execution until maybe Half Life 2?

>>9557745
I played Quake 3 on Dreamcast too. It was cool as hell playing an FPS online on console with kb/m before the OG xbox even existed, but it played like shit over dialup. 4 player local split-screen, on the other hand? Goldeneye and Perfect Dark didn't even come close. The maps and general gameplay of Dreamcast Quake 3 suited split-screen multiplayer better than anything else on consoles at the time.
PSO's online functioned much better than Q3's though, as it's netcode was designed with dialup internet and global multiplayer in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9558138
No. The Gamecube version made big improvements over DC, fixed alot of issues, and added a ton of new content. BB made small improvements and added some extra content to the Gamecube version. Both Gamecube and BB added QOL improvements that I wouldn't want to go back to not having. Most importantly though, BB implemented server-side saving. It meant sacrificing offline play entirely, but in return, cheating was much less rampant, and you no longer had to worry about losing your unequipped items to some jackass freezing your game with an action replay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558330
BB is the best version for online. GCN is the best version for offline play. Compared to DC, GCN doubles the number of dungeuns, adds new character classes, completely overhauls and rebalances the classes for the better, adds an absolute fuckton of new rare weapons to find (the main reason to play the game long-term) and makes their droprates almost reasonable compared to the absurdly low droprates on DC. The Spread Needle is no longer so OP as to completely dominate online play to the point where you won't get a single hit in if a teammate is using one. It fixes the glitch that allowed players to teamkill. It fixes the glitch that allowed players to go through locked doors. You no longer drop your money and equipped weapon when you die, to be ganked by other players. It adds a quick item select like the one in Monster Hunter that makes it MUCH easier to use items and spells that aren't assigned to your main 6 buttons. (On DC, you're stuck with JUST those 6 actions, at least two of which will be your basic attacks. Have fun juggling all those spells if you're a spellcaster) Spells now go up to Lv 30 instead of capping at Lv 15, and only Spellcasters can go above level 20, giving you an actual reason to use a spellcaster. GCN also adds splitscreen multiplayer, which is the best reason to play it. You can play online on private servers, either through a Gamecube with a broadband adapter, or a Wii with a lan adapter, but be warned; you have to take alot of precautions playing any console version online. Any rando in your lobby or your game can potentially freeze your game with a cheat device, causing you to lose all unequipped items on your character. If you're playing online on DC you'll also have to worry about these same cheat device randos overwriting your character data with a Lv 1 NPC named NOL.
Blue Burst is much more secure online; you can play with randos without worry, but there's no offline at all.
Honestly, don't bother with DC.

>>9549194
I've never tried it myself, but it seems like this control scheme would probably work just fine if you got used to it. I grew up on NES, so I'm used to attack being on a left face button, and jump being on a right face button. With MMX I added dashing to L, and with MMZ I added secondary weapon to R. With newer games I just added new buttons to what I was already used to from older games. Just because these controls work perfectly fine and feel natural to me after playing action platformers this way for decades, doesn't make it the only good control scheme. If you're a youngster whose first game was Halo, Minecraft, or Souls, it makes sense that you might gravitate towards controls that put your primary actions on shoulder buttons. Putting your primary actions on shoulder buttons is completely unnecessary in a game where you don't need to use the right analog stick to move your camera, but that doesn't mean that it's /wrong/ either. It's just different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560581
The upcoming Persona 3 Portable Steam port is going to be very noob friendly, just pay $20 and you're good to go, no need to mod anything or fuck with emulation settings.

The advantages of P3P over FES are full party control out of the box (no need for a mod) and a female MC route with all new social links. But you'll lose out on the 3D overworld, all 3D cutscenes AND all anime (FMV style) cutscenes. See the webm for a quick comparison. Even the dungeon crawling parts that are still 3D will have lower poly models compared to FES. And you also lose out on the post-game story expansion, The Answer (which is similar to the third semester in P4G and P5R).

So, if you're not tech illiterate, playing FES emulated AND modded can be a much better experience. Mods wise I'd recommend:
- full party control + no fatigue*
https://pastebin.com/xjnhHL5e
(just save the pnach file to the PCSX2's cheat folder)
- widescreen fixes
https://gamebanana.com/mods/33852
https://gamebanana.com/mods/33843
- undub if you're a weeb, as the PS2 versions of both P3 and P4 are EN VA only, although I personally find the EN voices more charming
https://gamebanana.com/mods/292547
https://gamebanana.com/mods/413136

*fatigue is a fucking annoying mechanic unique to Persona 3 where party members get "tired" after dungeon crawling for a bit and this will even affect their real world availability for the next few days, I prefer just patching it the fuck out, but you do you, just delete the lines in the pnach file if you think it's cheating

No. Nintendo Power is an absurdly bad magazine that ended up getting a very undeserved positive reputation on the Internet due to being the only American Nintendo magazine. I can understand the nostalgia for the early "artwork and walkthroughs"-heavy issues from the 80s, but after video game journalism started EXISTING period, it's just an embarrassment really. It's bad for a video game magazine, it's bad for a Nintendo-only magazine, it's bad for an English video game magazine and it's bad for an English Nintendo-only magazine. And the only reason it's not bad for an AMERICAN Nintendo-only magazine is because there weren't any others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Im an lcd autist and there are 2 categories that i find fun:

Game&Watch clones: anything simple, yet addictive. This covers obviously game&watch, some various rip offs such as from Epoch and some of the stuff you would find being sold at RadioShack(license from various other companies) and stuff like Tigerstix in the 90s. Generally speaking, the less buttons and the less complex, the better. Thats why most Tiger games sucked, they were ambitious, but you cant do a true recreation of a console game on what they had. You CAN do complex lcd games, but they are a rarity that they are actually fun.

The other ones i prefer are more complex ones, but from the 2000s, when you could get away with doing actual rpg type games on them, such as various digimons, megaman battle network, pox, the one pokemon with the figures. You either have to do simple games or find a good way to present a lot of info on screen which you couldn't really do till the 2000s tech allowed it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558843
The Master System game came first, then the Genesis game, then Lost Stars (which also had a Master System or Game Gear port, one of the two).
The first Alex Kidd game was about a tyrant named Janken that was taking over Radaxian and Alex having to stop him. It's not a very creative story, but it does have some fluff to it compared to other platformers at the time, like Alex actually being the Prince of Radaxian (something he didn't know until his master told him) or how there's a level after the final boss to tie up a loose end. There's even a minor extended universe component as Igul, Alex's brother and Radaxian's known prince, is actually the protagonist of a game called "Pit Pot" that the producer made prior to making Alex Kidd.
Enchanted Castle follows up on the cliffhanger ending of the first game (Alex's family is mostly saved, but the king is missing he went on vacation and is totally fine) and doesn't make any pretense of having an actual plot like Miracle World did. Lost Stars goes full "Sonic", having a somewhat intricate storyline in the manual/other materials, but zero context in the game itself.

Honestly, I'm about to cash out most of my software collection. Diablo (D1 is my favorite game ever; I have a copy of Hellfire I got as a kid as well)
Shin Megami Tensei (Already have fuckin' Jack Bros, still need to rebuy Persona PSP and find a Junpei hat for maximum autism)
Kunio Kun (Mostly the new releases and compilations since my wife got me a couple)
Ninja Gaiden (Xbox era and into /v/ territory as well but they're solid games)
Panzer Dragoon (Got II and Saga in a massive lot a decade ago; sold the first and guess I could rebuy it if I really care)
For my vintage computer collection I'm keeping it to the following:
Wizardry (Shin Megami Tensei is spiritually derived from these)
Ultima (Cool for what they are)
Postal (Pure absurdity)
I've got some other odd stuff too but I think most of it is going to have to go. I'm keeping Liberty or Death. It's got a sweet poster.
